body: You can get up-to-date contact information from local authorities in Finland and Sweden by using the Roaring integration.

title: Prerequisites
body: You need an agreement with Roaring to use the integration. Roaring can guide you through getting the necessary agreements and permits.

title: Prerequisites
body: The contacts whose information you want to fetch must have their social security numbers stored as the Contact ID in FA Back.

title: Setting up
body: To set up the Roaring connection, see Set up Roaring connection.

title: Running contact information updates
body: To update contact information using the Roaring integration, go to the Contacts view, search for the contacts whose information you want to update, and select Roaring.io → Update from Finnish population register or Roaring.io → Update from Swedish population register at the bottom of the view.

title: Running contact information updates
body: The following fields in the Contact window are updated:

title: Running contact information updates
body: Name

title: Running contact information updates
body: Address

title: Running contact information updates
body: The following fields are updated only from the Swedish population register:

title: Running contact information updates
body: Tag group Deregistration is updated with the official reason code if the contact has been removed from the population register. The reason codes are listed on the Roaring website.

title: Running contact information updates
body: Key figure Death date is updated with the death date of a deceased person. This is accompanied by the Deregistration tag AV.

title: Running contact information updates
body: Key figure Guardian is updated with the social security number of the contact's legal guardian and the date of validity.

title: Related links
body: Communications in FA Back reference

title: Documents
body: You can store documents and links in the FA system by linking them to a contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order. You can then send the documents to your clients via email. FA also allows you to send documents to be signed by your client, and you can monitor the signing process.

title: Manage documents
body: FA allows you to store and link documents related to contacts, portfolios, securities, transactions, and trade orders. You can store documents by uploading them as files or linking them from an external source. This topic describes how you can search and manage documents on the level of individual contacts, portfolios, securities, transactions, or trade orders. To manage all documents in the FA system, see Administering documents in FA Admin guide.

title: Manage documents
body: When uploading documents, the supported file types are: PDF, DOC, DOCX, ODT, XLS, XLSX, PPT, PPTX, ODP, ODS, TXT, CSV, XML, PNG, JPG, RTF, and MP3.

title: Upload documents
body: You can add new documents in the Document tab of the Contact, Portfolio, Security, Transaction, or Trade order window, or in the Documents section of Overview or customer details. You can upload documents as files from your computer or link them from external sources (for linking documents, see Link external documents).

title: Upload documents
body: To add documents, do the following:

title: Upload documents
body: Open the contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order where you want to add documents and go to the Documents tab or section.

title: Upload documents
body: Click Upload file and select the documents from your computer.

title: Upload documents
body: The documents are added to the list. To search the documents, see Search documents.

title: Link external documents
body: You can also add documents as links to external sources such as URL addresses or your internal document library. Linked documents are listed the same way as documents in the system, but they have the icon and the extension ".link".

title: Link external documents
body: To upload a linked document, do the following:

title: Link external documents
body: Open the contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order where you want to add documents and go to the Documents tab or section.

title: Link external documents
body: Click Upload link, and fill in the fields:

title: Link external documents
body: Document name. Name shown in the document list.

title: Link external documents
body: Link to document. URL of the document. The link can point to, for example, a document stored online or in your internal document library.

title: Link external documents
body: Click Save.

title: Link external documents
body: The document is now linked to the system. If you need to edit a link, remove it and add it again. To search the documents, see Search documents.

title: Download documents
body: To download a document, right-click it and select Download document. The document is downloaded to your computer.

title: Modify documents
body: You can modify the name, tags or folder location of a document:

title: Modify documents
body: Right-click the document and select Modify document.

title: Modify documents
body: Modify the document information:

title: Modify documents
body: Rename. Change the document name or folder. You can use this field to move the document into or out of a sub-folder (you can't directly edit the document file path). For example, you can rename a document "Contracts/NewContract.pdf" to place it into a sub-folder called "Contracts". To move the document back into the parent folder from "Contracts", you can rename the document "../NewContract.pdf". You can't delete sub-folders.

title: Modify documents
body: Document tags. Change the document tags.

title: Modify documents
body: Click Save.

title: Modify documents
body: The document information is now modified.

title: Delete documents
body: To delete a document, do the following:

title: Delete documents
body: Right-click the document and select Delete document.

title: Delete documents
body: Click Yes.

title: Delete documents
body: The document is deleted and the list is updated.

title: Search documents
body: You can find uploaded or linked documents in the Documents tab of the corresponding window. You can also search documents in the Documents section of Overview for contacts and portfolios, or by opening a customer in the Customers view. You can search for documents by name, date, time, modifier, and tags.

title: Search documents
body: The documents are listed in a table that shows the document name, the document type as an icon, the date, time, and user who last modified the document, and the document tags. To see documents in sub-folders when searching, tick the checkbox next to the tree structure icon . You can enable this, for example, to see portfolio and transaction documents when viewing a contact. If a document folder has separate sub-folders, you can select them in a drop-down menu.

title: System security measures
body: The following measures prevent users from uploading harmful documents into the system:

title: System security measures
body: Maximum document size. To define the maximum file size users can upload, see Preference - Administration in FA Back reference. For example, if a typical file size is 10 MB, you can reject files larger than 25 MB.

title: System security measures
body: Limit document upload frequency. To control how many documents a user can upload and how frequently (for example, a user can upload 1 new document every 10 seconds), see Preference - Administration in FA Back reference. If the system detects suspiciously frequent document uploads from a single user, the user is prohibited from uploading documents for some time.

title: System security measures
body: Virus scanning. The system can scan all uploaded documents for viruses for additional security. If the system detects a virus, the document upload is prevented. By default, virus scanning is disabled. Contact FA if you want to enable virus scanning.

title: Related links
body: Preference - Administration in FA Back reference

title: Document signing
body: FA document signing allows you to:

title: Document signing
body: Send documents from the FA document bank to be signed by your clients with their BankID (Signicat signing service).

title: Document signing
body: Monitor the signing status of documents.

title: Document signing
body: Cancel document signing requests.

title: Document signing
body: FA provides Signicat services through FA agreements. We charge customers separately for these services.

title: Document signing
body: The following sections describe how you can ask the client for authentication to view the document and administer the document signing functionality.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Ask for authentication to view a document

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: When you send a document for signing, the system by default requires authentication (for example, BankID) from the signee before they can view the document. You can adjust this setting by doing the following:

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Go to Tools → Administer → Signicat sign.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: See the Don't require authentication before viewing the document field in the Authentication section.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: To require authentication from the signee, make sure the checkbox is unticked (default).

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: To disable the mandatory authentication, tick the checkbox.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Click Done.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Authentication settings are now saved and the system asks the signee to authenticate depending on your selection.

title: Administer document signing functionality
body: Administer document signing functionality

title: Administer document signing functionality
body: Before you can use the document signing functionality, FA needs to order the signing method from Signicat and finalise the configuration of the signing process for you.

title: Related links
body: Manage documents in FA User guide

title: Related links
body: Set up document signing notifications in FA Admin guide

title: Send documents for signing
body: FA allows you to send documents for signing to one or more of your clients. The signees receive a link to the document via email or SMS. When they have signed the document, you can download it in FA Back.

title: Send documents for signing
body: To send a document for signing, do the following:

title: Send documents for signing
body: Make sure the following signee details are defined in the Contact window:

title: Send documents for signing
body: Social security number or national identification number in Basic info tab, External ID field.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Email and Phone fields in Address info tab. The document link is sent to the contact's first email address and to their phone number if defined. The email address and phone number are required if you select to send signing notifications always. If you set signing notifications to "If valid email address/phone number is found", the corresponding field is required. For details on signing notification settings, see ???.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Upload documents in the Contact, Portfolio, Transaction or Trade order window, Documents tab. Add the "Document signing-Waiting" tag.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Go to the Contacts view and select the signee's contact. Click Document signing → Send documents for signing at the bottom of the view.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Check the Validation column of documents you want to send. If a document has errors, you need to correct them before it can be sent. Typically, errors relate to missing signee details (see step 1).

title: Send documents for signing
body: Click Send.

title: Send documents for signing
body: The system produces a notification that shows the number of documents sent and the number of errors. Sent documents are tagged with "Document signing-Pending". Documents with errors are tagged with "Document signing-Error".

title: Send documents for signing
body: The signee receives an email with a link to view and sign the sent documents. When they sign the document, the system saves it in the Documents tab of the window where you uploaded it (Contact, Portfolio, Transaction, or Trade order window). You can then download the signed document.

title: Add multiple signees
body: Add multiple signees

title: Add multiple signees
body: If you need multiple clients to sign the document, you can add signees who are not linked to the portfolio, transaction, or trade order:

title: Add multiple signees
body: Open the Contact window, Document signing tab of the main signee.

title: Add multiple signees
body: Create a list of signees from available contacts using the arrow buttons. The selected signees need to have the same contact details defined as the main signee (see step 1).

title: Add multiple signees
body: Click Save & close.

title: Add multiple signees
body: When you send a document for signing, all signees on the list now receive a link to the document.

title: Schedule document sending
body: You can schedule the system to send documents for signing on a regular basis. When you schedule document sending, the system tries to send all documents tagged with "Document signing-Waiting". If a document has errors, the parent objects of the document (portfolio or contact) are tagged with "Document signing-Error". The document itself is not tagged, so the system sends it after you correct the validation errors. For more information on scheduling, see Scheduling in FA Admin guide.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: FA allows you to track the signing status of documents so that you know, for example, which documents are waiting for their signees and which documents you need to make corrections for. You can use the following methods to open the Document status list window:

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Open Contacts, Portfolios, Transactions, or Trade orders view and select the ones to view documents for → Document signing → Monitor document signing status.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Go to Tools → Monitor → Document signing status.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: The window shows the following information for each document:

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Status

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Current signing status of the document. For the list of statuses and their meanings, see Document signing statuses.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Signers

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Number of signees that have signed the document out of the total number of signees.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Contact

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Contact, portfolio, transaction, or trade order under which the document is stored.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Document

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Name of the document.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Date sent

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Date when the document was sent for signing.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Last modified

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Last date and time the document information was modified.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Validation

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Errors in the document information, for example, missing signee details. The column is empty if no errors are found. The document can only be sent for signing when it has no errors.

title: Document signing statuses
body: The following document signing statuses and corresponding tags are available:

title: Document signing statuses
body: Not sent. The document is waiting to be sent for signing and has the tag "Document signing-Waiting".

title: Document signing statuses
body: Pending. The document is sent and waiting to be signed and has the tag "Document signing-Pending".

title: Document signing statuses
body: Error. The object that contains the document or contact information has errors. The document has the tag "Document signing-Error". Fix the errors and tag the document with "Document signing-Waiting".

title: Document signing statuses
body: Done. The document is signed and has the tag "Document signing-Done". Both the original and signed document are saved in the FA system.

title: Document signing statuses
body: Canceled. The document signing was canceled by the initiator, meaning the one who requested it. The document has the tag "Document signing-Canceled".

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: You can monitor the signing status of documents under a specific contact:

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Open the Contacts view and select the contact to monitor.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Click Document signing → Monitor document signing status to open the signing status window.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Check the Validation column for errors. For documents with errors, you can click on the contact name to open the Overview and edit the missing or incorrect information.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: You can use the same method for portfolios, transactions, and trade orders as well.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: You can also monitor the signing status of documents stored under contacts, portfolios, transactions, and trade orders in one window:

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Go to Tools → Monitor → Document signing status. The window that opens shows a list of all documents with a tag related to the document signing process.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Click the rows highlighted with "Error" to open the Overview. Edit the missing or incorrect information.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: To cancel a signing request, do the following:

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Open the Tasks view.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Filter the task list to find the request to cancel. Signing request task titles follow the pattern: "<datetime> Awaiting signature: <document path>".

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Use the My tasks list to cancel your own signing request.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Use the All tasks list to cancel someone else's signing request.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Open the signing request task and click Cancel signing request.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: The signing request is canceled both on the Signicat side and on the FA side. If you need to send the document for signing again, tag the document with "Document signing-Waiting" and follow the instructions in Send documents for signing.

title: Send documents via email
body: FA allows you to send documents stored under a contact, portfolio, transaction, or trade order to your clients via email.

title: Send documents via email
body: For sending reports, the process is different (see Send reports via email).

title: Send documents via email
body: To send documents via email, do the following:

title: Send documents via email
body: Add the tag "Document sending-Waiting" to the documents you want to send.

title: Send documents via email
body: Go to Tools → Send documents via emails and use the checkboxes on the left side of the window to select which documents to send.

title: Send documents via email
body: Fill in the fields:

title: Send documents via email
body: Source of reporting addresses

title: Send documents via email
body: Source of the recipient email addresses. Select "Contact" to use the email address defined in the Contact window, Address info tab. Select "Portfolio" to use the email address defined in the Portfolio window, Reporting tab. You can see the email addresses fetched the source in the Recipient email address(es) column.

title: Send documents via email
body: Email template

title: Send documents via email
body: Email message template defined in Preference → Reporting → Email. For more information about email templates, see Send and receive emails and SMS messages.

title: Send documents via email
body: Click Send.

title: Send documents via email
body: The documents are sent to the client.

title: Key figures for contacts, portfolios and securities
body: Configurable key figures allow you to define what key figure values you want to store on your contacts, portfolios and securities. Key figures allow you to store a time series of values of your choice. For example, you can store fee percentages that change over time to your portfolios, or your key figure on your instruments, extending the possibilities of storing data into FA.

title: Transaction window
body: Transaction window allows you to define a new transaction or to view and modify the information of existing transactions.

title: Transaction window
body: You can open the Transaction window from any of the transaction listings available in FA: in addition to searching for transactions in the Transactions view, transactions are also visible in the Transaction listing on the Overview and Positions view. You can open the transaction information in the transaction window by double-clicking the transaction or by right-clicking the transaction and choosing Modify.

title: Transaction window
body: When creating a new transaction, first you have to choose the type of the security you are creating the transaction to. This affects the fields available in the window: for example, accrued interests are only available for bonds and such and not available for regular stocks. Choose the type either from the menu, or when creating a transaction through an existing transaction or security, the type is pre-selected for you.

title: Transaction information
body: For a new transaction, the transaction information is defined in the fields visible - the fields available vary slightly depending on the basic transaction type chosen. A red star indicates a mandatory field.

title: Transaction information
body: The fields available are:

title: Transaction information
body: Portfolio*

title: Transaction information
body: The portfolio you want to create the transaction in.

title: Transaction information
body: Basic type

title: Transaction information
body: The chosen basic type of the transaction or allows you to choose the basic type: the chosen of the basic type influences the fields available for defining the transaction. The available basic types are cash, stock, bond, fund, discount, deposit, currency, option and future.

title: Transaction information
body: Security*

title: Transaction information
body: the security related to the transaction. The + icon next to the security field allows you to create a new security directly in the transaction window in case the security to be linked to you transaction cannot yet be found from the system. When choosing to create a new security, the possible security types are filtered to match the security base type chosen to the transaction. When you save the security, it is automatically selected as the security of the transaction.

title: Transaction information
body: Transaction type*

title: Transaction information
body: The transaction type from the alternatives, which are defined in Transaction type Preferences. You can only see the transaction types which are linked to the selected security's security type, or if no security is selected, linked to all security types with the selected security type's base type.

title: Transaction information
body: Account*

title: Transaction information
body: The account to record the money transactions caused by the transaction. You can see only accounts with the security, transaction or portfolio currency. Shared accounts (an account of the same customer's portfolio defined to be shared to the portfolios of the customer, the account of a main portfolio automatically shared to its sub-portfolios, or an account of a subportfolio shared to all parent portfolio's subportfolios) are indicated with a star * before account number and name. You can see the shared account's portfolio in brackets.

title: Transaction information
body: When there is an exchange rate related to the transaction, appropriate FX rate field(s) are available in the Transaction window below the account field (see Transaction's currency below for more details).

title: Transaction information
body: Report FX rate

title: Transaction information
body: The appropriate report exchange rate, or exchange rate between you transaction's security's currency and you portfolio's currency, for the transaction. You can fetch the exchange rate to the field with a question mark (?), when the system sets the exchange rate to be the transaction day's market price of the currency. If no market price is can be found for the transaction date, the latest available market price is used.

title: Transaction information
body: Account FX rate

title: Transaction information
body: The appropriate account exchange rate, or exchange rate between you transaction's security's currency and you portfolio's account's currency, for the transaction. You can fetch the exchange rate to the field with a question mark (?), when the system sets the exchange rate to be the transaction day's market price of the currency. If no market price is can be found for the transaction date, the latest available market price is used.

title: Transaction information
body: Transaction dates are defined in the appropriate date fields below the transaction type.

title: Transaction information
body: Transaction date*

title: Transaction information
body: The transaction date. Transaction date determines when the the transaction actually occurred (i.e. when the transaction originally took effect). Positions, portfolio's content and most reports are most often based on the transaction date. For more information on how to select dates, see Selecting dates.

title: Transaction information
body: Trade time

title: Transaction information
body: The time of the trade either in the format of hh:mm, for example 14:30, or in the format of hh:mm:ss, for example 14:30:15.

title: Transaction information
body: Settlement date

title: Transaction information
body: The settlement date of the transaction. For more information on how to select dates, see Selecting dates. You can also set the settlement date the following ways:

title: Transaction information
body: Enable the settlement date to be set automatically by enabling the "Set transaction's settlement date automatically based on transaction date" in Transactions Preferences. When enabled, whenever you enter a transaction date, the settlement date is automatically set a certain number of business days from the transaction date. If the Enable settlement date has been enabled for the transaction's security (or cash transaction's currency's) in the Security window, the number of days defined in Settlement date is used to calculate the settlement date for trades in that security, or if not defined per security, the Amount of business days configured in Transactions Preferences is used to calculate the settlement date. In addition to how many business days trades take to settle, the transaction's security's (or cash transaction's currency's) holiday calendar is used to determine which days are business days.

title: Transaction information
body: Set the settlement date a certain number of days from the transaction date by writing a number between 1 and 99 to the field: the number you insert indicates the number of business days the settlement date is set after the transaction date. The transaction's security's (or cash transaction's currency's) holiday calendar is used to determine which days are business days.

title: Transaction information
body: Calculate the settlement date with a question mark (?), when the system calculates the settlement date based on the transaction date, transaction's security's (or cash transaction's currency's) holiday calendar, and the number of business days defined either for the security (if the Enable settlement date has been enabled), or if not defined per security, in the preferences.

title: Transaction information
body: Status

title: Transaction information
body: The status of the transaction: Accepted, Deleted, Not finished. Only accepted transactions are visible in the portfolio and have an effect on the portfolio total and portfolio reports. Transactions with any status are searchable in the transactions view.

title: Transaction information
body: Hidden

title: Transaction information
body: Hide this transaction from the Overview’s transaction listing. Hidden transactions still affect your positions, but they are not shown on the Overview’s transaction listing. This allows you to filter the Overview to only show transactions you need in your day-to-day work to get an overview of your client’s investments, while you can access other transactions through the Transactions view. This is especially useful for bookkeeping transactions, such as deferrals or value adjustments, which don’t directly affect how much you own, but only alter the position’s values for bookkeeping purposes.

title: Transaction information
body: The transaction itself, or the values of the transaction, are defined in the appropriate number fields in the window, starting from the left below the dates.

title: Transaction information
body: Amount

title: Transaction information
body: The amount / denomination of the transaction. Amount can have as many decimals as defined in the Security type Preferences or as the block size of the transaction's security - only the allowed number of decimals can be inputted in the transaction window.

title: Transaction information
body: Coefficient

title: Transaction information
body: The coefficient of the transaction. The field is available only for transaction of the basic type bond with a linked index (i.e. for index linked bonds). You can also set the coefficient the following ways:

title: Transaction information
body: If linked index information is defined for the security (Extra info tab of the Security window), you can calculate the coefficient to the transaction by typing a question mark (?) to the field, when the system automatically calculates the coefficient based on the linked index and the index base value.

title: Transaction information
body: Insert the reference index value with a question mark (e.g. 123?) into the field, when the system automatically calculates the coefficient based on the inserted reference index and the index base value.

title: Transaction information
body: Unit price

title: Transaction information
body: The unit price of the chosen security. You can also set the unit price the following ways:

title: Transaction information
body: Fetch the unit price to the field with a question mark (?), when the system sets the unit price to be the transaction day's market price of the transaction's security. If no market price can be found for the transaction date, the latest available market price is used.

title: Transaction information
body: For bonds, when appropriate bond information has been defined for the bond security, the unit price can also be calculated by setting a yield to the unit price field with % (e.g. 3.45%), when the system automatically calculates the unit price according to YTM.

title: Transaction information
body: Price

title: Transaction information
body: The system automatically calculates the price of the transaction based on the inserted values. If the transaction required an account exchange rate, price and all other values below it are also shown against the account's currency, converted with the defined account exchange rate.

title: Transaction information
body: When there are taxes related to the transaction, choose the tax type from the alternatives and define the tax to the corresponding field. The tax can either add or reduce the trade amount: the effect of the tax is defined in the transaction type settings, in Transaction type Preferences. You can define two separate taxes on a transaction: the upper tax field calculates the amount of the tax from the price of the transaction (for example tax from dividend), while the lower tax field calculates the amount of the tax from the fees (for example VAT from transaction costs).

title: Transaction information
body: Tax type

title: Transaction information
body: The tax type from alternatives, which are defined in Tax type Preferences (see Preference - Taxation). The tax type defines the type of tax in question (for example Capital gains tax or Withholding tax).

title: Transaction information
body: Tax

title: Transaction information
body: The tax of the transaction. A plain numerical value is interpreted in terms of money, and there are different ways you can trigger the system to calculate the tax on your transaction:

title: Transaction information
body: When you define the tax with as a percentage (% sign after the numerical value), the system calculates the money value of the tax from the price of the transaction (upper tax field) or from the fees (lower tax field).

title: Transaction information
body: You can also calculate the tax with a question mark (?), when the tax percentage and the tax type are fetched from default tax rates (applicable only if an appropriate default tax rate has been defined).

title: Transaction information
body: Accrued interest

title: Transaction information
body: Record the paid / received accrued interest of the transaction, up to the settlement date of the transaction. The field is available only for transaction of the base type BOND If coupon/fixing information is defined for the security (Extra info tab of the Security window), you can calculate the accrued interest to the transaction by typing a question mark (?) to the field. The system automatically calculates the accrued interest up to the settlement date.

title: Transaction information
body: Accrual

title: Transaction information
body: Record the paid/received accrued income included in your transaction's unit price. The field is available only for transactions of the base type FUND. Unit price already includes the accrued income, and thus accrual doesn’t have an effect on your transaction's trade amount. If accrual component is recorded within security's market data (Market data info tab of the Security window), you can calculate the accrual to the transaction by typing a question mark (?) to the field. The system automatically calculates the accrual on the transaction date. This field is used for accrued income management with mutual funds: NAV of a fund includes accrued income, but when you subscribe into a fund, you pay for the income accrued before your subscription, and when you redeem your shares, you receive the accrued income not yet paid out. Your position's purchase value excludes the paid accrual recorded on your transaction, while your position's purchase unit price includes accrual.

title: Transaction information
body: When there are costs related to the transaction, either choose the cost type from the alternatives and define the cost to the corresponding field, or click the edit icon to define a more detailed break-down of transaction's costs (see Break-down of transaction's costs below for more details). The cost can either add or reduce the trade amount: the effect of the cost is defined in the transaction type settings, in Transaction type Preferences. The cost can be defined for a transaction in two fields: the upper cost field has a default name Credit fee, while the lower cost field has a default name Fee.

title: Transaction information
body: Cost type

title: Transaction information
body: The cost type from alternatives, defined in Transaction cost types. The cost type defines the type of cost in question (for example Advisory fee, Custodian fee or Broker commission). If you don't select a cost type, your costs are identified as generic Credit fee and Fee.

title: Transaction information
body: Credit fee

title: Transaction information
body: The credit fee of your transaction. A plain numerical value is interpreted in terms of money, and there are different ways you can trigger the system to calculate the tax on your transaction:

title: Transaction information
body: When you define the fee as a percentage (% sign after the numerical value), the system automatically calculates the money value of the fee from the price of the transaction.

title: Transaction information
body: The edit icon next to the field allows you to define a more detailed Break-down of transaction's costs, allowing you to break down your transaction costs into as many different types of costs as you need.

title: Transaction information
body: Fee

title: Transaction information
body: The fee of your transaction. A plain numerical value is interpreted in terms of money, and there are different ways you can trigger the system to calculate the tax on your transaction:

title: Transaction information
body: When you define the fee as a percentage (% sign after the numerical value), the system automatically calculates the money value of the fee from the price of the transaction.

title: Transaction information
body: If transaction-related portfolio fees (fee type "transaction") are defined to the portfolio in the Fees tab of the Portfolio window, the defined fee can be applied to this field by typing a question mark (?) to the field. The system calculates the value of the fee by using the defined transaction fee percentage.

title: Transaction information
body: The edit icon next to the field allows you to define a more detailed Break-down of transaction's costs, allowing you to break down your transaction costs into as many different types of costs as you need.

title: Transaction information
body: Total trade amount

title: Transaction information
body: The system automatically calculates the total trade amount of the transaction based on the values in the Total column, taking into account the tax and fees. Modifying the total trade amount will adjust the value in the Unit price field in order for the values to add up correctly. If there are no values defined for the Amount and Unit price fields, setting the total trade amount will set the total trade amount to the Amount field and 1 to the Unit price field. If the transaction required an account exchange rate, trade amount and all other values above it are also shown against the account's currency, converted with the defined account exchange rate.

title: Transaction information
body: Below the transaction values on the left, you can define additional information to your transaction.

title: Transaction information
body: Reference

title: Transaction information
body: The reference of the transaction. You can automatically generate the reference number to a transaction with a question mark (?), when the system generates a reference number to the transaction with the formula portfolio ID * 100 000 + transaction external ID + control number. Portfolio ID is used as a basis of the reference number by default, but if the portfolio ID is not a number, then portfolio external ID is used. If the portfolio external ID is not a number, then portfolio database ID is used. The control number is calculated based on the formula defined for forming reference numbers.

title: Transaction information
body: Counter

title: Transaction information
body: A counter and a counter portfolio for your transaction. The first dropdown for the counter contact first lists contacts of the type Counter party and Custody in alphabetical order, and then the rest of the contacts within the system in alphabetical order. The second dropdown for the counter portfolio lists all portfolios within the system in alphabetical order.

title: Transaction information
body: Market place

title: Transaction information
body: The marketplace (MIC) of the transaction from the alternatives, which are defined in Marketplace Preferences. To find a marketplace, start typing the MIC code or marketplace name in the field.

title: Transaction information
body: Settlement place

title: Transaction information
body: The settlement place (BIC) of the transaction from the alternatives, which are defined in Settlement place Preferences.

title: Transaction information
body: External ID

title: Transaction information
body: External ID / number of your transaction. When creating a transaction, the system automatically generates an external ID for it by determining the next available number - the available number depends on whether you have selected transaction numbering to be handled on the portfolio or contact level within Transaction no. level field in the Contact window. For example, if the largest external ID in your portfolio at the moment is 123, the next transaction would get the external ID of 124. You can also modify the external ID manually or have the system re-generate it with the next available number by typing in a question mark (?). External ID can also include letters and other non-numeric characters - however, these can only be added manually and are not considered by the automatic external ID generation.

title: Transaction information
body: Priority

title: Transaction information
body: The intra-day priority of the transaction with a number (-1, 0, 1, 2, 3 etc.). The transaction with the lowest priority has the highest number defined in the priority field (0 is lower than 1 and -1 is lower than 0). The default priority is 0. The priority field is used to order the transaction within one day, in other words, to define which transactions take effect first. If priorities have not been used, but if trade times are defined, the transactions take effect in trade time order (empty trade time is interpreted as 00:00 and takes effect before transactions with a later trade time). If priorities or trade times are not used, the transactions within a day are ordered based on the transaction external ID.

title: Transaction information
body: Receive date

title: Transaction information
body: The date when you created the original trade order or received it from the client.

title: Transaction information
body: Receive time

title: Transaction information
body: The time when you created the original trade order or received it from the client. Enter the time either in the format of hh:mm, for example 14:30, or in the format of hh:mm:ss, for example 14:30:15.

title: Transaction information
body: In the booked transaction information at the bottom of the window, you can define booked values for your transaction, for example, if an earlier transaction is entered and recorded to the portfolio at a later date. For example, Add transactions often have Booked values, e.g. different values for the original purchase, and different values for recording the transaction to the portfolio.

title: Transaction information
body: Date

title: Transaction information
body: The booked transaction date.

title: Transaction information
body: Booked exchange rate

title: Transaction information
body: The exchange rate, if the original exchange rate is different from the new exchange rate of the transaction (if no exchange rate is needed, define 1 as the exchange rate). The booked exchange rate can also be fetched to the field with a question mark (?), when the system fetches the exchange rate to be the booked transaction day's market price of the currency. If no market price is can be found for the transaction date, the latest available market price is used.

title: Transaction information
body: Booked trade amount

title: Transaction information
body: The booked trade amount. The booked trade amount can also be fetched to the field with a question mark (?), when the system fetches the booked transaction day's market price of the transaction's security (if no market price is can be found for the booked transaction date, the latest available market price is used), and calculates the booked trade amount by multiplying the fetched price with the defined amount.

title: Transaction information
body: The second security and ratio fields are available only if the selected transaction type has been configured to support a second security. The transaction type configurations can be found from Transaction type Preferences (see Transaction types).

title: Transaction information
body: Second security

title: Transaction information
body: The second security for the transaction. For example, for issues, the second security often shows which security the issue is based on.

title: Transaction information
body: Ratio

title: Transaction information
body: The ratio in the form of x:x, for example 1:2. For example, for splits, the ratio tells the split ratio.

title: Transaction information
body: Removed accrual

title: Transaction information
body: Removed accrual from security A when making an exchange for security B. The removed accrual is sold and realized on the exchange date. The field is available only for transactions of the base type FUND.

title: Transaction information
body: Payment date field allows you to separate between payment date and settlement date.

title: Transaction information
body: Payment date

title: Transaction information
body: The payment date of your transaction, when the payment date is different from your transaction's settlement date. Payment date field is available for security trades linked to an account, since there is no need to separately define a payment date to cash transactions. Payment date is optional, and only affects the date when your account balance changes.

title: Transaction information
body: Override FIFO field allows you to sell a specific purchase lot in FIFO through linking transactions together to override the otherwise calculated FIFO chain.

title: Transaction information
body: Override FIFO (ext ID)

title: Transaction information
body: The external ID of the transaction you want to link this transaction to in order to override FIFO. When calculating FIFO, transactions linked together through this field are considered first, and all remaining transactions are ordered based on FIFO logic. This allows you, for example, to link a "sell" transaction to a specific "buy" transaction in order to sell a specific purchase lot over FIFO.

title: Transaction information
body: You can also override FIFO with a fraction of lots. To increase the amount on an existing lot without creating a new lot, use the Equalization credit (EQCR) transaction type and specify the external ID of the existing lot you want to increase in the Override FIFO (ext ID) field. To decrease the amount on a specific lot without leaving out any purchase lots from the FIFO chain, use equalization debit (EQDE) transaction type and specify the external ID of the existing lot you want to increase in the Override FIFO (ext ID) field.

title: Transaction information
body: The linked transaction has to pass though the following validation:

title: Transaction information
body: Transaction with the defined External ID exists in the same portfolio.

title: Transaction information
body: Transaction is not yet linked to another transaction. If you already linked a "buy" to another "sell", you cannot link it to another "sell".

title: Transaction information
body: Security of the linked transaction must be the same as the current transaction's security. You can only override FIFO within a position in the same security.

title: Transaction information
body: The amount of the linked transaction must be equal or greater than the current transaction's amount.

title: Transaction information
body: Transaction status of the linked transaction must be "Accepted".

title: Transaction information
body: Description on statement

title: Transaction information
body: An optional description of the transaction, which is visible for example on the bank statement report.

title: Transaction information
body: Internal info

title: Transaction information
body: An optional description of the transaction, which is visible only internally in the Transaction window.

title: Transaction information
body: Tags

title: Transaction information
body: Tags from the alternatives defined in Tags Preferences (see Preference - Tags). Tags can be defined in three different ways:

title: Transaction information
body: Grouped tags (select one): you can select one tag from each tag group, grouped in separate dropdowns. Only one tag in each tag group can be chosen. To group tags in a dropdown, defined them with a hyphen as "group - tag".

title: Transaction information
body: Grouped tags (select multiple): you can select multiple tags from each tag group, grouped as separate sets of checkboxes. You can check multiple tags within each tag group. To group tags as a set of checkboxes, defined them with a colon as "group : tag".

title: Transaction information
body: Individual tags: search for individual tags by typing the tag in the field and choosing the correct tag from the list below the field - all available tags are shown from the downward arrow on the keyboard. You can select multiple individual tags.

title: Breakdown of transaction costs
body: Due to regulation, recording only two separate costs in your transaction might not be enough for recording detailed ex-post disclosure of costs. Break-down of transaction costs allows you to categorize and break down your transaction costs in as much detail as you need, allowing you to track all your costs with accuracy and transparency.

title: Breakdown of transaction costs
body: In order to break down your transaction costs further, you can click the edit icon next to each of the cost fields and define a detailed break-down of costs. With this approach, you can easily record in your break-down of costs to as many different types of costs as you need - the window is pre-filled with all the cost types you have defined in Transaction cost type Preferences (see Transaction cost types). You can separately define the break-down for both of the cost fields, allowing you to maintain up to two sets of break-downs of costs, and if you need to break down your costs into more categories, just add new transaction cost types in preferences.

title: Breakdown of transaction costs
body: When you save your break-down of costs with Save & Close, the cost field in the Transaction window shows the aggregated total of your broken-down costs. If you have defined a break-down of costs, you cannot any more edit the value directly in the cost fields - re-open the break-down of costs to make modifications to your individual costs. In addition, you can use the transaction cost types to categorize your break-down of costs as well - for example, you can break down one-off costs into the upper cost field and ongoing costs into the lower cost field, and categorize the break-downs accordingly.

title: Transaction cost categorization
body: Due to regulation, the different cost types you enter in the detailed break-down of transaction costs should also be categorized into proper categories to extensively record ex-post disclosure of costs. Transaction cost categorization allows you to categorize all your transaction costs as Portfolio (investment service costs), Security (product costs) or 3rd (third party payments), and then further as One-off charges, On-going charges, Charges related to transactions, Charges related to ancillary services or Incidental charges, or you can use up to five Other costs categories with accuracy and transparency.

title: Transaction cost categorization
body: Transaction cost categories can be set through Preferences either on your cost transactions or transaction costs:

title: Transaction cost categorization
body: Categorizing cost transactions. You can categorize all your cost transactions through Transaction type Preferences. When a category is set to a cost transaction, the trade amount of such a transaction is summed into the Every time you save a transaction, ex-post disclosure of costs is calculated based on the categorization you have defined and the values you have entered on your transaction. All cost categories are available as columns on the transaction listings in security currency (no abbreviation), portfolio currency (identified with abbreviation (PF)) and account currency (identified with abbreviation (ACC)), categorized as investment service costs (identified with abbreviation (PF)), product costs (identified with abbreviation (sec)) and third party payments (identified with abbreviation (3rd)). If the column name only includes one abbreviation, that indicates the category and the values are shown in security currency, and if the column name includes both abbreviations, they are stated in order (currency, category). For example, column "On-going charges (PF)" shows on-going charges in security currency categorized as investment service costs, "On-going charges (ACC, PF)" shows on-going charges in account currency categorized as investment service costs, and "On-going charges (PF, PF)" shows on-going charges in portfolio currency categorized as investment service costs.selected cost category. You can for example categorize the total trade amount of your asset management fees as On-going charges.

title: Transaction cost categorization
body: Categorizing transaction costs. You can categorize all your transaction cost types through Transaction cost type Preferences, allowing you to associate a category to each of them. When a category is set to a transaction cost type, the amount of the cost is summed into the selected cost category. You can for example categorize the brokerage fees you record on your transactions as Charges related to transactions.

title: Transaction cost categorization
body: Every time you save a transaction, ex-post disclosure of costs is calculated based on the categorization you have defined and the values you have entered on your transaction. All cost categories are available as columns on the transaction listings in security currency (no abbreviation), portfolio currency (identified with abbreviation (PF)) and account currency (identified with abbreviation (ACC)), categorized as investment service costs (identified with abbreviation (PF)), product costs (identified with abbreviation (sec)) and third party payments (identified with abbreviation (3rd)). If the column name only includes one abbreviation, that indicates the category and the values are shown in security currency, and if the column name includes both abbreviations, they are stated in order (currency, category). For example, column "On-going charges (PF)" shows on-going charges in security currency categorized as investment service costs, "On-going charges (ACC, PF)" shows on-going charges in account currency categorized as investment service costs, and "On-going charges (PF, PF)" shows on-going charges in portfolio currency categorized as investment service costs.

title: Transaction cost categorization
body: The columns on the transaction listing allow you to see an ex-post disclosure of your transaction costs. Full ex-post disclosure of costs, calculated based on the defined cost categories, is available then on Analytics+ or on a specific Ex-post costs report.

title: Transaction currency
body: In some cases, for example when buying a foreign stock, you may need to define an exchange rate to your transaction. FA supports defining two separate exchange rates between two out of three possibly currencies involved:

title: Transaction currency
body: Report FX rate - you need to define an exchange rate for your transaction when the currency of the transaction / currency of the transaction's security is different from the portfolio's currency the transaction is recorded in. This is called the Report FX rate.

title: Transaction currency
body: Account FX rate - you need to define an exchange rate for your transaction when the currency of the transaction / currency of the transaction's security is different from the account's currency the transaction is recorded against. This is called the Account FX rate.

title: Transaction currency
body: When the transaction's currency differs from the portfolio's currency or account's currency, there are additional FX rate fields visible in the Transaction window. These fields allow you to define the required FX rates and to see the transaction's values converted into account or report currency, depending on the involved FX rates.

title: Transaction currency
body: All positions on the Overview and many of FA's standard reports announced all values in the portfolio's currency, thus defining an appropriate exchange rate is important for the system to be able to convert the transaction values properly for reporting.

title: Transaction currency
body: The fields available are:

title: Transaction currency
body: Report FX rate / Account FX rate

title: Transaction currency
body: The exchange rate of the transaction against the portfolio's currency (report FX rate) or portfolio's account's currency (account FX rate). The exchange rate fields are available only when the transaction requires an exchange rate, and only the appropriate fields are available. In addition, if account and report FX rates would be the same, only the account FX rate field is available to prevent you having to define the same exchange rate twice.

title: Transaction currency
body: Whenever you need to enter an FX rate, the caption of the FX rate field clearly indicates which FX rate it is expecting. This is based on the currency crosses defined in the system: for example, when you need an FX rate between EUR and NOK, the system either asks for EUR/NOK (i.e. 7,5) or NOK/EUR (i.e. 0,15), depending on which cross it can find.

title: Transaction currency
body: You can also fetch the FX rate to the field with a question mark (?), when the system fetches the rate from the shown currency cross, and if a cross cannot be found, then calculates the rate for a missing cross through existing crosses and system’s base currency. Triangulation works through the system's base currency, and requires crosses that have been defined with the system's base currency. For example, the system can calculate and FX rate for SEK/USD based on existing crosses EUR/SEK and EUR/USD, when EUR is the system's base currency.

title: Transaction currency
body: In addition, you can define the FX rate in different formats, and the system automatically transfers the defined FX rate to decimal format. For example, in a situation where the transaction currency is USD and the portfolio currency is EUR, you can enter the FX rate of the these currencies either as 1 EUR = 0,740 USD or 1 USD = 1,35 EUR. FA always expects the FX rate as indicated by the caption of the FX rate field: if such an exchange rate is available, you can insert it in the exchange rate field in decimal format. On the other hand, if the exchange rate is announced in the opposite way,you can insert it in the field as an invert, and the system automatically calculates the needed FX rate. The FX rate in the example can be defined in the following formats:

title: Transaction currency
body: Decimal: 1,35

title: Transaction currency
body: Invert:

title: Transaction currency
body: Total ()

title: Transaction currency
body: If the transaction and account currencies are different, there are two Total columns visible, showing the transaction's values in different currencies. These columns are named with the currencies used: the first column tells the the value in the transaction / security currency, and the second column shows the values converted into account or report currency with the provided FX rate. The transaction's values are always shown in the transaction / security currency on the left. On the right, the transaction's values are by default shown converted into account currency with the account FX rate, unless you only have the report FX rate involved, when the transaction's values are shown converted into report currency with the report FX rate.

title: Transaction currency
body: In addition, if you are buying or selling a currency, and if you have an account with in currency you are trading, the effect is shown on the account. For example, when buying US Dollars (USD), and the portfolio has an USD account, the purchase will be recorded as an increase in this USD account instead of creating a position for USD in the securities section. Enter a currency buy or sell by selecting the currency, defining the amount, using unit price 1, and setting the relevant FX rate for valuation.

title: Transaction values / Booked values
body: In some cases, for example, when adding/transferring existing holdings of a client to his portfolio maintained in FA, you might want to record the dates and values of when the holding was actually bought, but at the same time keep track of when the position was transferred into the client's portfolio. Alternatively, you might want to re-valuate your positions with booked values at the end of the accounting year for, while still keeping track of the dates and prices you originally paid for your purchase.

title: Transaction values / Booked values
body: For such scenarios, you can use two different sets of fields within the Transaction window: transaction values and booked values.

title: Transaction values / Booked values
body: Transaction values ("original values")

title: Transaction values / Booked values
body: The fields in the upper part of the Transaction window (e.g. Transaction date, Amount, Unit price, Costs / Taxes, Trade amount and FX rates) allow you to always record the actual / original / real transaction information, i.e. when the transaction actually took place. These fields should always be filled in with real values - if you have defined only the transaction values, your transaction takes effect in your portfolio on the transaction date.

title: Transaction values / Booked values
body: Booked values

title: Transaction values / Booked values
body: The booked transaction fields at the bottom of the Transaction window (e.g. Booked transaction date, Booked exchange rate and Booked trade amount) allow you to re-valuate your transaction on a later date with booked values, i.e. when the transaction was transferred or re-valuated in your portfolio. These fields should be filled in ONLY IF you want to re-valuate your transaction, and they should always be defined for a later date than the transaction date (i.e. booked values are always after the transaction date) - if you have defined the booked values, your transaction by default takes effect in your portfolio on the booked date instead of the transaction date.

title: Transaction values / Booked values
body: Once you have defined both the "original" transaction values and the booked values, you are able to track your portfolio against both values from various places in FA:

title: Transaction values / Booked values
body: The basic principle is that capital gains are always calculated from the "original" transaction values for taxation purposes, while performance (TWR) of your portfolio is always calculated from the booked values for you to be able to follow the performance of the portfolio only after everything has been transferred under your management.

title: Transaction values / Booked values
body: In addition, Overview, Positions view and Analytics+ allows you to view multiple values, such as purchase value, change, realized and unrealized profits, based on both "original" transaction values and the booked values - original values are always identified with (o) in the column name, while other values are calculated based on the booked values.

title: Transaction values / Booked values
body: Similarly, multiple reports allow you to generate them either with Original purchase value (i.e. "original" transaction values) or Transaction purchase value (i.e. booked values).

title: Separating between payment date and settlement date
body: Payment date field allows to separate between settlement date, i.e. when a trade is settled, and payment date, i.e. when a trade is paid, when these dates differ. In addition, you can use payment date on a trade to consider it pre-paid. Separating between payment date and settlement date allows you to manage pre-paid trades, and provides you with better control over your cash balance for cash reconciliation purposes.

title: Separating between payment date and settlement date
body: Use the payment date field only when you specifically need it, i.e. when payment date differs from settlement date or when you are entering pre-paid trades.

title: Separating between payment date and settlement date
body: Payment date allows you to manage pre-paid trades and control unsettled cash.

title: Manage pre-paid trades
body: If your payment date is prior to the transaction date, your transaction is considered as "pre-paid". Your cash is deducted already on payment date prior to transaction date.

title: Manage pre-paid trades
body: Example:

title: Manage pre-paid trades
body: You bought a fund on 18.12.2019, but you pre-paid for the purchase two days before, and it takes two days for the securities to settle. Set Transaction date as 18.12.2019, Settlement date as 20.12.2019 and payment date as 16.12.2019.

title: Manage pre-paid trades
body: → your cash balance is deducted on 16.12., the fund position appears in your portfolio on 18.12. and the fund position is shown as settled on 20.12.

title: Control unsettled cash
body: If your payment date is after the transaction date but prior to the settlement date, payment date is used to control unsettled cash. Your cash is deducted on transaction date as usual, but your cash is settled on payment date instead of settlement date.

title: Control unsettled cash
body: Example:

title: Control unsettled cash
body: You bought a foreign stock on 16.12.2019, your cash balance settles a day after, while it takes four days for the securities to settle. Set Transaction date as 16.12.2019, settlement date as 20.12.2019, and payment date as 17.12.2019.

title: Control unsettled cash
body: → your cash balance is deducted and the stock position appears in your portfolio on 16.12., but they are both shown as unsettled. Your cash balance is shown as settled on 17.12. and your stock position on 20.12.

title: Confirmation messages
body: The system can be configured to display confirmation messages, if a created transaction is going to result in negative account balance or negative amount of a security. The confirmation messages can be enabled in Transaction Preferences. Even though the confirmation messages are enabled, transactions resulting in negative account balance or amount can still be created: the confirmation messages help notice such errors in creating transactions.

title: Confirmation messages
body: Negative account balance - If saving the transaction would result in negative account balance, the transaction has to be accepted in Accept transaction window with Yes / No alternatives.

title: Confirmation messages
body: Negative amount - If saving the transaction would result in negative amount of the security, the transaction has to be accepted in Accept transaction window with Yes / No alternatives.

title: Bookkeeping
body: Bookkeeping tab allows you to see the bookkeeping postings of your transaction.

title: Documents
body: Documents tab allows you to manage documents related to your transaction.

title: Saving a transaction
body: Saving a transaction saves it in the system, and automatically triggers a report recalculation to update the effect of your transaction into your portfolio's positions. If you saved your transaction on the Overview to the selected contact or portfolio, the effect of the transaction within your portfolio's positions is immediate - otherwise the effect of the transaction within your portfolio's position report date takes effect as soon as the report recalculation has gone through.

title: Saving a transaction
body: If you don't wish the system to automatically trigger the report recalculation every time you save a transaction (useful for example when migrating a lot of data for a long time period), you can disable Update reports immediately from Preferences. If disabled, the report recalculation is scheduled to be run next night instead, and the effect of the transaction is not visible in you report data before that.

title: Saving a transaction
body: At the bottom of the Transaction window, you can:

title: Saving a transaction
body: Save & close – Saves the transaction / changes made to the transaction information and closes the window.

title: Saving a transaction
body: Save – Saves the changes made to the transaction information.

title: Saving a transaction
body: Save & new – Saves the transaction / changes made to the transaction information and opens a new, empty transaction window for you to create a new transaction.

title: Saving a transaction
body: Save & new (copy) – Saves the transaction / changes made to the transaction information and opens a new transaction window prefilled with information from the transaction you copied. This function copies all other transaction information except for the External ID and Reference.

title: Related links
body: Manage transactions in FA User guide

title: Rebalance window
body: You can create model portfolios or investment plans and use them to keep your investment portfolios in balance. Rebalancing creates trade orders to buy and sell securities according to the model. For general information about rebalancing approaches and for instructions, see Rebalance in FA User guide.

title: Rebalance window
body: The Rebalance window allows you to define the rebalance parameters and the securities to rebalance. The window lists securities in the portfolio or model portfolio/ investment plan linked to the rebalanced portfolio and indicates the shares of these securities in the investment portfolio and model. The portfolio account is also included in rebalancing.

title: Rebalance window
body: At the top of the Rebalance window, you can define the rebalancing parameters.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Affected portfolios

title: Affected portfolios
body: The Affected portfolios section defines which portfolios are rebalanced.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Rebalance against

title: Affected portfolios
body: Target for rebalancing, in order of descending priority. The system uses the first target in the list if defined. Otherwise, the system the target with the next highest priority. The targets can be:

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Model portfolio", "Investment plan" – Model portfolio or investment plan linked to the portfolio.

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Portfolio itself" – Target shares you specify in the Rebalance window.

title: Affected portfolios
body: "Empty portfolio" – An option to empty the portfolio – this will set all the new shares as 0% and sell everything, regardless of the linked model or plan.

title: Affected portfolios
body: Include sub-portfolios

title: Affected portfolios
body: Aggregates positions and investment plan/ model portfolio contents also from the rebalanced portfolio's subportfolios. This allows you to divide holdings into subportfolios and rebalance everything at once through the main portfolio. Trade orders are created either to the main portfolio or the sub-portfolios based on which portfolio or portfolio's investment plan / model portfolio the trade order's security can be found in: for sells of existing positions, trade orders are created in the same portfolio where the position currently is, and for buys, trade orders are created in the same portfolio which has the position in the investment plan / model portfolio.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Rebalance parameters

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The Rebalance parameters section defines rebalancing logic.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Date

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The rebalancing date. This date affects:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The market prices, rebalanced portfolio shares, trade order amounts. The percentage shares of securities in the portfolio are determined based on the market prices on the rebalancing date. The market prices on this date are used to calculate the amount in the suggested trade orders.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The content of the model portfolio/ investment plan. The target shares are fetched based on the selected rebalancing date

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Restrict rebalancing to accounts

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Restrict rebalancing to only reach the target level for portfolio accounts, without any other buys or sells. This feature has different effects depending on the rebalance method (buying with extra cash or using cash from sells) – see Rebalance methods.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With the conservative rebalancing method, securities are bought and sold only to achieve the target level of the account. If the account has excess cash, the selected securities (largest first) are bought as long as there is available cash but nothing is sold. If the account has a lack of cash, the selected securities (largest first) are sold until the account reaches the target level - nothing is bought and securities are sold only to rebalance the account to the defined level.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With the exchange method, if the account balance is below the target, it is first rebalanced with sells. After this, the excess cash from sells is used to buy the securities to be rebalanced, but securities are sold only to cover all the necessary buys. If there are Executable sell trade orders, the cash coming in from these is taken into account when selling the securities.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: With full rebalance, if the account balance is below the target, it is first rebalanced with sells. After this, the excess cash from sells is used to buy the securities to be rebalanced, but securities are sold only to cover all the necessary buys.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: You can also define the rebalance settings in Preference ("Define target range for portfolio's cash balance", "Define how much negative cash balance is increased by to cover all negative cash" and "Define how much positive cash balance is decreased by to ensure positive cash balance"). These preferences determine how rebalancing tries to achieve the target level for accounts. See Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Rebalance method

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Rebalancing approach: conservative rebalance, full rebalance, full rebalance including outstanding orders, exchange, invest cash, cover for cash, and model change (see Rebalance methods).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Filter out small trade orders based on

title: Rebalance parameters
body: The minimum size for the trade orders that rebalancing should create. The size restrictions don't apply if you sell an entire position away from the portfolio (see Rebalance). Set the minimum difference between the portfolio position and the model as:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Minimum change % (absolute/ percentage points)" - The difference in percentage points.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Minimum change % (relative / percentage change)" - The relative difference in percentage.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Minimum trade amount" - The minimum trade amount in portfolio currency. Alternatively, you can define a Minimum trade amount for each of your securities (see Security window).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Position is within min/max share" - The difference defined with the minimum and maximum thresholds in the model. Trade orders are created only if your position deviates outside of the minimum and maximum thresholds. The minimum trade amount for each trade order is calculated as follows:

title: Rebalance parameters
body: For "buy": ( target share - min share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance parameters
body: For "sell": ( max share - target share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Positions that don't have the thresholds specified int the model are rebalanced without filtering when "Position is within min/max share" is selected.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Use cash from accounts

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Accounts to use for buys if you select to buy with extra cash in the portfolio. This option allows you to keep your portfolio fully invested and exclude certain accounts (for example, accrued fee accounts) from rebalancing.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "All accounts" – Use cash on all accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Cash accounts" – Use cash on the accounts marked as "cash accounts" in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Cash and credit accounts" – Use cash on cash and credit accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Default account only" – Use cash on the portfolio's default account – the first account in the list in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab. If this account is a credit account, you can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Use portfolio credit

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Use credit account for buys. Choose if you want to use the positive account balance and available credit for buys, and if you want to cover the negative balance. The option is shown if you selected "All accounts", "Cash and credit accounts" or "Default account only" in Use cash from accounts.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Don't use portfolio credit" – Use only positive balance on the credit account for buys, without repaying the used credit.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Use portfolio credit" – Use available credit and positive balance on the credit account for buys, without repaying the used credit.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Repay portfolio credit" – Use positive balance on the credit account. In case of negative balance, rebalance the credit account account to 0. The cash is rebalanced to the default portfolio account, and you can then repay the credit manually. If a portfolio has no accounts other than the credit account, the credit is repaid automatically.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: Calculate fees to trade orders

title: Rebalance parameters
body: An option to calculate fees, or to estimate the effect of an upcoming fee when generating buy and sell trade orders. If a fee is calculated, the effect of the fee is taken into account when determining how many units you can buy with you available cash and how much money you get from sells. This allows you to estimate the effects of upcoming transaction fees more accurately. Fees are also saved in the Fees field for each trade order.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Don't calculate fees" - Don't calculate fees in trade orders.

title: Rebalance parameters
body: "Calculate portfolio specific fees" - Calculate a transaction fee defined in the portfolio (Portfolio window, Fees tab).

title: Rebalance parameters
