The caption of the field indicates the currency cross you should fill in, and you can also fetch the FX rate with a question mark (?), when the system fetches the latest available price for the contract date from the currency cross.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Sell / Buy

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Pre-filled to be opposite to the buy / sell selection you made above. Determines the direction of the second cashflow, i.e. whether the currency and amount you enter on the same row next to the field are "buy" or "sell". If you change this selection, the above buy / sell selection is changed accordingly.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Currency

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Select the currency of the second cashflow, i.e. the currency you are buying / selling.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Amount

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Define how much of the selected currency you are buying / selling. This amount is pre-filled based on the amount you entered on the upper row and the FX rate you defined. If you update this amount, the system automatically calculates the FX rate to ensure all calculations match.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Accounts section allows you to define the accounts affected on the forward date, i.e. which accounts the buy and sell cashflows are directed to.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Account (Currency)

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Select the account you want to direct the cashflow in the selected currency to. The account selections always correspond to the cashflow you have defined on the same row on the left, and the caption of the account field indicates which currency cashflow you should select the account for. The dropdown lists accounts in the selected currency within your selected portfolio, and the account filed is pre-filled if your selected portfolio only has one account in the selected currency.

title: Security, forward cashflows and cashflows for FX Forwards
body: When saving an FX Forward, the system creates a contract security, produces forward cashflow positions into your portfolio between the contract date and the end of the contract, and generates relevant cashflow transaction for the end of the contract.

title: FX Swap
body: Contract type FX Swap is an agreement between two parties to exchange currency between two parties, in which they swap holdings in one currency for a holding in another currency for a fixed period of time.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: For FX Swap, the contract-specific fields allow you to fill in information that is relevant for entering an FX Swap contract into the system. You can fill in the information of the near leg and the far leg of your FX Swap in the same window - the fields allow you to manage both spot-forward swaps as well as forward-forward swaps.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: The fields available are:

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Contract date

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Date when the contract beings. For FX Swap, the near leg cashflows occur on the contract date (if the near leg is a spot), and the far leg the forward cashflow positions appear in your portfolio on the contract date.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Near leg and Far leg sections allow you to define all relevant details of the swap. You can define your swap in terms of the two cashflows you would be exchanging once in the beginning (near leg) and then back in the end (far leg) - information relevant to each cashflow is shown on the same row.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Near leg section allows you to define all relevant details for the beginning of the swap. The near leg of your swap can be either a spot or a forward, and the near leg fields are the same as the contract-specific fields for FX Forward with the following special characters:

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Near leg type - select the type of the near leg as an FX Spot or an FX Forward (available from FA 3.10 onward). For contracts created prior to FA 3.10, the system interprets your near leg's type based on its length: if the leg's settlement date is two days or less after the contract date (taking into account the involved currencies' holiday calendars), the near leg is an FX Spot, otherwise the near leg is an FX Forward.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Near period - select the length of the near leg of your swap. The near period is used to calculate the settlement date of the near leg cashflows.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: By default, the near leg is assumed to be a spot, and the near period is pre-filled to be 2D. When the near period is a spot, the settlement date is calculated as in contract-specific fields for FX Spots (settlement date = contract date + 2D), and transaction date is the same as the contract date.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: In case the near leg is a forward, you can change the length of the near leg to be something else, for example 1W or 1M. When the near leg is a forward, the settlement date and transaction date are calculated as in contract-specific fields for FX Forwards (settlement date = contract date + 2D + near period).

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Far leg section allows you to define all relevant details for the end of the swap. The far leg of your swap is always a forward, and the buy / sell selections should be opposite to your near leg, the currency selections the same as in your near leg, and the first cashflows amount the same as in your near leg. When you change these values in either of the legs, the other leg is changed accordingly. The far leg fields are similar to the contract-specific fields for FX Forward with the following special characters:

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Far leg type

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Shows the type of the far leg, which is always FX Forward (available from FA 3.10 onward). Far period - select the length of the far leg of your swap. The far period is used to calculate the settlement date of the far leg cashflows by adding the selected period into the near leg settlement date (far leg settlement date = near leg settlement date + period). Otherwise, setting the settlement date and transaction date work as in contract-specific fields for FX Forwards.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Buy / Sell

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled to be opposite to the buy / sell selection you made in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). Determines the direction of the far leg cashflow, i.e. if you "buy" in your near leg, then you "sell" in your far leg. If you change this selection, the near leg buy / sell selection is changed accordingly. Currency - pre-filled to be the same as the currency you selected in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). The currencies have to be the same for the same cashflow for near leg and far leg - you are exchanging the currencies back and forth. If you change this currency, the near leg currency is changed accordingly.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Amount

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled to be the same as the amount you defined in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). One of the amounts you are exchanging in the beginning has to be the same as you are exchanging at the end. If you change this amount, the near leg amount for the same cashflow is updated accordingly.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Points

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Allows you to define how much the far leg FX rate changes compared to the near leg FX rate. A point is the smallest amount a price can move in a currency quote, and 1 point = 0.0001 change in far leg FX rate from the near leg FX rate. Points are used to calculate the far leg FX rate as near leg FX rate + points/10 000 = far leg FX rate. For example, 1.1464 + 10 points = 1.1464 + 0.001 = 1.1474

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: FX rate (currency cross)

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled based on the points you entered. The far FX rate is the price you agreed to do the exchange between the two currencies you selected. The FX rate is used to convert the amount you have entered on the upper row to the amount on the lower row, and the caption of the field indicates the currency cross you should fill in.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Sell / Buy

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled to be opposite to the buy / sell selection you made above and opposite to the Buy / Sell selection you made in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). If you change this selection, the above buy / sell selection and the near leg buy / sell selection is changed accordingly.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Currency

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled to be the same as the currency you selected in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). The currencies have to be the same for the same cashflow for near leg and far leg - you are exchanging the currencies back and forth. If you change this currency, the near leg currency is changed accordingly.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Amount

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled based on the amount you entered on the upper row and the FX rate you defined. If you update this amount, the system automatically calculates the FX rate to ensure all calculations match.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Accounts section allows you to define the accounts affected for the dates defined on the near leg and the far leg, i.e. which accounts the buy and sell cashflows are directed to in the beginning and in the end of the contract.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Account (Currency)

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Select the account you want to direct the cashflow in the selected currency to. The account selections always correspond to the cashflow you have defined on the same row on the left, and the caption of the account field indicates which currency cashflow you should select the account for. The dropdown lists accounts in the selected currency within your selected portfolio, and the account filed is pre-filled if your selected portfolio only has one account in the selected currency.

title: Security, forward cashflows and cashflows for FX Swaps
body: When saving an FX Swap, the system creates a contract security, generates relevant cashflows in the beginning of the contract, produces forward cashflow positions into your portfolio between the contract date and the end of the contract, and generates relevant cashflow transaction for the end of the contract.

title: Corporate action window
body: In the Corporate action run window, you can do three things: define the corporate action information, run the corporate action to selected portfolios, or schedule the corporate action to be run on a future date. The Corporate action run window also allows you to save the corporate action after completing each section so you can close it and return to work on it later on.

title: Corporate action window
body: For step-by-step instructions on creating, defining, and running corporate actions, see Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios in FA User guide.

title: Corporate action
body: The fields you need to fill in to define a corporate action depend on the selected corporate action type. For all corporate action types, you need to define the security and transaction type to use, and then define the relevant values, dates, and memo. To learn about the fields specific to each corporate action type, see Corporate action types in FA User guide.

title: Corporate action run
body: A corporate action run is defined in the fields below the corporate action information. The following fields are available:

title: Corporate action run
body: Groups, contacts, portfolios*

title: Corporate action run
body: The portfolios you want to run the selected corporate action to. You can run a corporate action to all portfolios (visible as #All), a group of portfolios (visible with Group name), a specific customer's portfolios (visible as Customer name (ID)), or a single portfolio (visible as Customer name - Portfolio name (ID)). The system creates transactions in the portfolios included in the selection. For example, dividends are recorded only in portfolios within the selection containing the dividend security.

title: Corporate action run
body: Juridical form/tax country (for example: Private person/Finland)

title: Corporate action run
body: The combinations of the portfolio's juridical forms and tax countries found in the selected portfolios. If the portfolios the run targets include several combinations, they are all listed. You can then define the transaction type, tax rate, and tax type separately for each combination. You can also define default tax rates to use in the corporate action run in Preference (see Preference - Taxation). If a default tax type matches the current run, the system automatically fills in the default tax rates.

title: Corporate action run
body: Transaction type - Choose the transaction type of the transactions created based on the corporate action. By default, the system suggests you use the same transaction type you selected in the corporate action information for all combinations of juridical form/tax country. You can change the transaction type for certain combinations. For example, you can create transactions of a specific type for private persons in Finland.

title: Corporate action run
body: Tax rate - Define the tax rate to use in transactions for this combination of juridical form/tax country.

title: Corporate action run
body: Tax type - Define the tax type to use in transactions for this combination of juridical form/tax country.

title: Corporate action run
body: Exchange rates

title: Corporate action run
body: The exchange rate if the security currency of the corporate action and the portfolio currency are different. Define the exchange rate of the portfolio's currency against the security currency. The field is available for all combinations of the security and portfolio currencies related to the run, and you can define each exchange rate separately. The format of the field is the following: Portfolio currency/Security currency (for example: EUR/USD). To fetch the exchange rate automatically, enter a question mark (?) in the field. The system sets the exchange rate as the market price of the currency on the day of the corporate action. If no market price is found for the date, the system uses the latest available market price.

title: Scheduled corporate action run
body: A corporate action is scheduled for a future date in the fields below the corporate action run information, and the system automatically performs the run. When scheduling a corporate action, you do not know, for example, the exchange rate. During the run, the system uses the latest FX rate from the market price entries of the currency to ensure that the corporate action is converted with an accurate exchange rate. The following fields are available:

title: Scheduled corporate action run
body: Date

title: Scheduled corporate action run
body: The date you want the corporate action to run on. A corporate action should not be run before the corporate action date or before all transactions in the selected portfolios are in the system to ensure the corporate action runs against accurate data.

title: Scheduled corporate action run
body: Time

title: Scheduled corporate action run
body: The time you want your corporate action to run on, specified in the format HH:MM. Running a corporate action generates transactions and triggers report recalculation which might take time for a large number of portfolios.

title: Scheduled corporate action run
body: Example:

title: Scheduled corporate action run
body: You receive information of a dividend on September 20th, and the dividend will be paid on November 11th. When scheduling the dividend in September, you do not know what the FX rate is in November. When running the corporate action in November, the system fetches the latest FX rate from the market price entries of the currency to ensure that the corporate action is converted with an accurate exchange rate.

title: Transactions from a corporate action run
body: Running a corporate action creates transactions in the selected portfolios based on the position of the corporate action security on the morning of the corporate action date (meaning the position after the previous day's transactions) and the information defined in the Corporate action run window. The system only creates transactions in portfolios that own the corporate action security on the morning of the corporate action date. The transactions cause the corporate action to show up in the affected portfolios.

title: Transactions from a corporate action run
body: The system automatically determines the account for the transactions when running the corporate action. If the transaction type you defined in the Corporate action run window has a cash effect, the following logic is used to set the transaction account:

title: Transactions from a corporate action run
body: If the portfolio has an account with the same currency as the corporate action security, it is set as the transaction account.

title: Transactions from a corporate action run
body: If no portfolio account is found with the same currency as the corporate action security, the portfolio's default account is set as the transaction account.

title: Transactions from a corporate action run
body: If the portfolio has no accounts, the shared accounts of the portfolio are used with the same logic: If found, the shared account with the same currency as the corporate action security is set as the transaction account. If no such shared account is found, the shared default account is used instead (from FA 3.5 onward, corporate action run also considers accounts shared through the "Shared to all linked contact's portfolios" option).

title: Related links
body: Corporate actions in FA User guide

title: Related links
body: Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios in FA User guide

title: Report window
body: Report window allows you to generate reports - you can either generate individual reports, mass-generate reports to a group of portfolios, send reports via email, or publish reports to documents. Everything related to reporting is available in the Report window.

title: Report window
body: You can access the report window either from the New report option in the New menu, or from the New report icon on Overview and standard search views. In addition, you can open reports as tabs on the Overview.

title: Generate reports
body: To generate a report, start by selecting a report from the listing on the left. The reports listing allows you to select from:

title: Generate reports
body: Any standard reports (see Available standard reports).

title: Generate reports
body: Any query-based report templates you have saved from the Queries view. Report templates can only be used as a PDF, and are indicated in the listing with the suffix (PDF) after report template name.

title: Generate reports
body: Any PDF report template you have uploaded to the system. Report templates can only be used as a PDF, and are indicated in the listing with the suffix (PDF) after report template name.

title: Generate reports
body: Any custom reports developed for you.

title: Generate reports
body: Any custom report developed and published through JSReport.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Based on the report you selected, available report parameters on the right vary. Parameters that are available only for certain reports are shown below in brackets.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Some fields, for example, Transaction type or Security type, allow you to restrict the content of the report to show only certain kind of data - if not filled in, all data within your portfolio during the reporting time is included in the report.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Saved search

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Available if you run reports from the Transactions or Trade orders view). The saved search you want to create the report for. See Generate reports for transactions and trade orders in FA User guide for details.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Customer, Group, Portfolio*

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Available if you run reports from the top menu or from the Overview). Customer, group or portfolio you want to create the report for. You can set the report to be created for multiple customers, portfolios or groups by choosing it from the field and clicking the + button: the selection is listed below the field, and you can add other selections to the listing. You can delete a customer, portfolio or group listed below the field with the - button. You can create a report with the following selections:

title: Report generation parameters
body: Choosing one or more portfolios (if a portfolio is chosen on the Overview, this portfolio is the default selection for the report)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Choosing one or more contacts (if a contact is chosen on the Overview, this contact is the default selection for the report)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Choosing one or more groups

title: Report generation parameters
body: Choosing #All, when the chosen report is created for all portfolios in the system

title: Report generation parameters
body: Date

title: Report generation parameters
body: The Report date or Date period (see also Selecting dates). Depending on the nature of the report and the data shown on the report, you need to either select a single date, a date range or no date at all. For example, reports showing positions or allocation naturally show data for a single date, whereas reports showing transactions or a history of figures naturally react to a date range.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Note that if you combine individual reports or create report package, the report date (or the end date of the period) is the same for all reports. If you enter different dates or date ranges, the system picks up the last one you entered and applies it to all reports. To have individual reports generated for different dates, you should save them as different packages and then combine as a report package.

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Purchase value)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Original purchase price and Transaction purchase price. The selection tells whether the reports always show the transaction purchase price, or whether the reports show the original purchase price of transactions that original transaction information is defined to. The default selection of the purchase price used can be set in Preferences - Transactions.

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Securities)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Security, if you want to create a report based on only one security

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Grouping)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Grouping of your report's content from alternatives Security type, Security, Class 1 - 5, Country, Market place, Currency, Counter, Issuer, Asset class or Asset type (available for older reports), or from alternatives Portfolio, All portfolios, Portfolio type, Portfolio's country, Portfolio's juridical form, Portfolio's contact, Security, Position, Linked security, Type, Subtype, Basetype, Class 1 - 5, Country, Currency, Marketplace, Settlementplace, Tag, Issuer, Asset class, Asset type, Assets and liabilities and Assets and accounts by category.

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Allocation group)

title: Report generation parameters
body: If you have selected a grouping that involves asset classes or asset types, select also the allocation group (defined in Preferences) you want to use.

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Transaction types)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Transaction types to be printed out on the created report from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Transaction types. You can choose multiple transaction types from the list by holding the Ctrl key and choosing the needed transaction types.

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Reference, Counter)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Reference or counter.

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Tags)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Transaction tags to limit the transactions included in the report.

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Security type)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Security types to be printed out on the created report from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Security types. You can choose multiple security types from the list by holding the Ctrl key and choosing the needed security types.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Language

title: Report generation parameters
body: language of the report: Customer/Portfolio language, Svenska, Suomi or English. The languages available are defined in Preferences - Language. The default selection is the Language of portfolio/customer, when the language of the report will be the language set for the portfolio in the Basic info of the Portfolio window. In order to being able to print reports in different languages, you would need to define appropriate translations for security types, transaction types, etc. thorough Preferences - General - Internationalization.

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Print reports even if empty)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Print out report(s) even if they would be empty, e.g. the report has no content. If checked, report will always be printed out, even if it has no content. If not checked, when creating only one report, the report is not opened if it is empty, and when creating multiple reports (either per portfolio or per customer), empty reports are not created into the specified folder.

title: Report generation parameters
body: File format

title: Report generation parameters
body: File format of the report to be created: PDF, XLS, XLSX, CSV, TXT, DOCX, PPTX, RTF, XML, XHTML.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Output type

title: Report generation parameters
body: Output type of the report.

title: Report generation parameters
body: One report - Prints out one combined report for the selection of the Customer, Group, Portfolio selection, if possible. The generated report ones up on the screen after the report generation is finished.

title: Report generation parameters
body: One report (background) - Similar to the One report option, but the report is run in the background (a good choice when generating large reports or reports requiring heavy calculations - when the report is run in the background, the FA Portfolio can be used while the report is generating). The report can be found in the Generated reports tab.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Report per customer or Report per portfolio - Prints out a report (or combination of reports is multiple reports are chosen) for each customer or each portfolio chosen in Customer, Group, Portfolio. The individual reports can be found in the Generated reports tab.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Report per customer via email or Report per portfolio via email - See sending reports via email for more details.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Report per customer to documents or Report per portfolio to documents - See publishing reports to documents for more details.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Report per customer (list emails below) - Report is sent to a list of email addresses you provide instead of emails linked to the contact.

title: Report generation parameters
body: Report per portfolio (list emails below) - Report is sent to a list of email addresses you provide instead of emails linked to the portfolio.

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Emails (comma-separated))

title: Report generation parameters
body: List of customer email addresses (comma-separated) to which the report is sent. The report is sent to these emails instead of emails linked to the contact or portfolio. If you don't define any emails, the report is generated but not sent. If some emails have errors, you can see an error in the Email(s) column of the report summary (see Status report from report generation).

title: Report generation parameters
body: The field is visible only if you chose the output type Report per customer (list emails below) or Report per portfolio (list emails below).

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Folder name)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Name for the folder for the created reports. All characters except for special charaters, such as "+", "%", "*", and so on, are allowed. The reports are saved to a folder with the defined name, and can be downloaded from the Generated reports tab. Folder name you define here is extended with a time stamp when the folder was created (following the syntax Folder-yyyyMMdd-hhmmss), ensuring that even if you use the same folder name, reports within one generation always go to a unique folder (available from FA 3.11 onward).

title: Report generation parameters
body: The field is visible only if you chose the output type other than One report.

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Email template)

title: Report generation parameters
body: Select the email template you want to use. This field is visible only if the output type is Report via email, and it pre-fills the template used when sending reports via email.(Available from FA 3.11 onward).

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Transaction tags)

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Available if you run reports from the Transactions view). Single select transaction tags to assign to the transactions after they are reported, for example, "Reporting - Confirmation sent". You can use this option to filter out reported transactions in the Transactions view and exclude them from future reports.

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Trade order tags)

title: Report generation parameters
body: (Available if you run reports from the Trade orders view). Single select trade order tags to assign to the trade orders after they are reported, for example, "Reporting - Confirmation sent". You can use this option to filter out reported trade orders in the Trade orders view and exclude them from future reports.

title: Report generation parameters
body: After filling in the report parameters, you can click the Generate report button to download the report to your computer or save the report to a folder you specified so you can view it in the Generated reports tab. If you selected Reports via email as the output type, you need to fill in the fields for email reporting in the new window that opens.

title: Report generation parameters
body: The combination of the selected group, customer and portfolio together with the selected output type allows you to efficiently create different kinds of reports. For example, selecting a group in the group, customer and portfolio field and defining the output type to be either report per portfolio or report per customer generates separate reports per each portfolio/customer within the group. You don't need to create the same report for each portfolio/customer separately, but you can generate these at once and fetch the individual reports from the Generated reports tab after the reports have been created. Additionally, if selecting a group in the group, customer and portfolio field and defining the output type to be one report, you get one aggregated report of the contents of the portfolios within the group.

title: Combined report
body: You can combine multiple different reports for the same date in a single PDF file. Individual reports are placed on separate pages within the file.

title: Combined report
body: To generate a combined report, multi-select reports from the report list in the order you want them to appear in your combined report - the order is also indicated at the bottom of the Report window.

title: Report packages
body: You can save your combined report and the report generation parameters for later use as a report package. You can make the report package visible only to yourself or choose to share the report package with other FA users.

title: Report packages
body: To save selected reports as a report package:

title: Report packages
body: Open the report window and multi-select reports as a combined report. Essentially, saving a report package means saving a combined report for later use.

title: Report packages
body: Define the report generation parameters on the right. Note that you can only select one date range or date for all the reports included in the package.

title: Report packages
body: Once you are happy with the content and order of your combined report, click Save as a new report package.

title: Report packages
body: Define a name for your report package - this name will be used in the file name of the generated report (define the report file naming syntax in Reporting Preferences), and to list the report in the report package listing.

title: Report packages
body: Decide which users you want to share the report package with, i.e. which users can see and use the report package in the Report window:

title: Report packages
body: Not shared – The package is saved only for you to use.

title: Report packages
body: Shared with everyone – The package is available for everyone to use.

title: Report packages
body: Shared with group xx – The package is available for the users in a specific user group. The list of groups includes user roles assigned in the FA Admin Console app (for details, see User details pane).

title: Report packages
body: Shared with role xx – The package is available for the users with a user role defined on the system level.

title: Report packages
body: To use a saved report package:

title: Report packages
body: Open the Report window.

title: Report packages
body: The Report window opened from the Portfolios and Contacts views, and from the New → New report menu features all report packages you created before.

title: Report packages
body: The Report window opened from the Transactions or Trade orders view features only report packages that include at least one transaction or trade order report.

title: Report packages
body: Select the report package at the bottom of the Report window. You can see the reports within the package in the combined report section, and the report generation parameters are shown on the right.

title: Report packages
body: If your selected report package contains a report that is no longer available (the report has been uninstalled after you have saved your report package), you'll get a confirmation to generate the report package anyway without the unavailable report(s).

title: Report packages
body: If needed, edit the report generation parameters on the right.

title: Report packages
body: Click Generate report.

title: Report packages
body: To delete a report package, select it from the list and click the trash can icon . This will not delete the reports within the package, but just remove the report package from the list. To modify your report package, make changes in the selected reports or the parameters and click Update report package.

title: Report packages
body: If you have a report package selected, you can't select reports since the report listing shows you the content of your report package - Unselect the report package to use the Report window manually again.

title: Generated reports
body: The Generated reports tab shows the generated reports. The reports are visible on the tab sheet when multiple reports or reports on background are generated: one report created opens up on directly, but multiple reports are stored on the server, where they can be downloaded to be viewed on your computer.

title: Generated reports
body: The reports are saved in folders, which are named based on the information given on the previous tab sheet. The folders can be seen at the top of the window, in the Folders area: you can download a folder to your computer, or you can view the reports saved inside this folder by clicking it from the folder listing. The reports within the chosen folder appear at the bottom of the window, in the Reports area.

title: Generated reports
body: The following functions are available through right-clicking the folder or report

title: Generated reports
body: Open

title: Generated reports
body: Opens and downloads the chosen folder as a zip package or an individual report (a folder or report can also be opened by double-clicking it).

title: Generated reports
body: Delete

title: Generated reports
body: Deletes the chosen folder or individual report.

title: Generated reports
body: The following buttons are available:

title: Generated reports
body: Delete reports

title: Generated reports
body: Deletes the chosen folder with all the reports in it.

title: Generated reports
body: Download reports (ZIP) (WIN)

title: Generated reports
body: Downloads the chosen folder as a zip folder, if there are multiple reports in the folder, or as a single file, if the folder only includes a single report. Use this button when you are using Windows operating system / Windows computer.

title: Generated reports
body: Download reports (ZIP) (OS)

title: Generated reports
body: Downloads the chosen folder as a zip folder, if there are multiple reports in the folder, or as a single file, if the folder only includes a single report. Use this button when you are using OS operating system / Mac computer.

title: Generated reports
body: Download reports (PDF)

title: Generated reports
body: Downloads all the reports in the chosen folder as one pdf file.

title: Status report from report generation
body: Whenever the system generates reports in the background and saves them under the Generated reports tab, the system produces a status report out of the generation. The status report is saved along with the report files into the same folder under the Generated reports tab - you can find it among the report files with the name Report_summary.csv. (Available from FA 3.11 onward)

title: Status report from report generation
body: The status report provides you with details on which reports were generated successfully and which reports failed, allowing you to more easily follow up and get a grasp of the status of your reporting. In addition to the success or failure of each report, the status report includes relevant information on which group, customer or portfolio the report was generated to, for which dates and with what file type. In addition, if you were sending reports via email, the email address the report was sent to is included in the status report. This allows you to easily replicate a generation, for example if a couple of reports failed to be generated while most of your reports were generated successfully.

title: Ongoing generations
body: The Ongoing generations tab sheet shows the ongoing report generations: if the report generation includes multiple reports, the progress of the generation is shown on this tab sheet. The report generation can also be cancelled on this tab sheet.

title: Log tab
body: The Log tab sheet shows the report generations performed and the history of email reporting: the tab sheet shows the date and time, when a report was created, as well as a description of the report generating activity.

title: Log tab
body: The following buttons are available:

title: Log tab
body: Clear

title: Log tab
body: Clears the log listing

title: Log tab
body: Refresh

title: Log tab
body: Refreshes the listing to show the latest actions.

title: Scheduled report generations
body: Scheduled report generations tab lists all the report packages that have been scheduled to be generated automatically by the system. The tab lists all report packages with a schedule defined for them (ordered by next upcoming generation), shows each packages' next scheduled generation, and allows you to remove or edit any given schedule directly through the tab. (Available from FA 3.11 onward)

title: Related links
body: Reporting in FA User guide

title: Yield curves view
body: The Yield curves view allows you to view the observations of a yield curve defined in the Yield curve Preferences.

title: Yield curves view
body: Yield curve is a curve showing several interest rates across different times - yield is actually only known with certainty for a few specific maturity dates, while the other maturities are calculated by interpolation. The Yield curves view allows you to identify these points the yield is know for on a specific date. Select a yield curve you want to view, and you can see the values for different dates for the different tenors (i.e. different maturities) associated with your curve. The values are picked up from the market data entires of the securities associated with the selected yield curve with different tenors.

title: Yield curves view
body: You can also export the results as an XLS file.

title: Analytics+
body: Analytics+ allows you to easily analyze your portfolios, providing you with an extensive set of analytical key figures to analyze your investments.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Setting up analysis

title: Setting up analysis
body: Choose if you need to analyze portfolios (Groups, contacts, portfolios tab) or securities (Securities tab).

title: Setting up analysis
body: For portfolios, analysis parameters are:

title: Setting up analysis
body: Group, customer or portfolio you want to analyze.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Grouping for your analysis. You can group your analysis with:

title: Setting up analysis
body: Portfolios.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Security-related parameters, such as asset classes and types, security type, classifications, countries, marketplace, currencies, issuer or issuer group.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Pre-defined combinations, such as Asset type and portfolio, Security type and subtype, Portfolio and sub portfolio, or Portfolio and asset type.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Custom grouping, when you can freely select the grouping levels from the available alternatives. If you want to include the actual position level in your analysis, select "Security", "Position" or "Positions by customer" as the last grouping option.

title: Setting up analysis
body: When grouping with asset type selection, you are also required to select which allocation group is used in grouping your analysis.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Date range for your analysis.

title: Setting up analysis
body: For securities, analysis parameters are:

title: Setting up analysis
body: Security you want to analyze (you can select multiple securities).

title: Setting up analysis
body: Date range for your analysis.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Benchmark index chosen from the general benchmarks defined in Preferences. To learn more, see Preference - Portfolios.

title: Setting up analysis
body: When you choose the parameters, the Analyze button turns black to indicate you changed your criteria and should update your analysis.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Analytics+ also allows you to save your frequently used analysis and different sets of selected columns for later use.

title: Results of the analysis
body: Based on your selected parameters, the analysis is presented as a table with analytical key figures accompanied with a return graph and allocation pie chart. Remember that your analysis (or the analytical key figures) can be exported as an Excel or PDF file, and the graphs at the bottom can be printed out or downloaded as a PDF or image files.

title: Table with analytical key figures
body: The table at the top allows you to select your desired columns from a wide range of different analytical figures. All the analytical figures are available for the selected time period and fixed time periods of 1, 3, 6, 9, 12 months and year-to-date (YTD). See below for a comprehensive list of available analytical figures.

title: Table with analytical key figures
body: You can also hide positions through right-clicking the table, allowing you to easily and effectively view the analysis only on the group level. Whether the positions are hidden or shown is remembered for your user name.

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: The graphs at the bottom visualize the overall performance for the selected time period, show the purchase value compare to market value, allowing you to track how your portfolios’ value has developed, and draws the current date's allocation for the selected portfolio(s).

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: You can easily re-draw the performance and allocation graphs for different visualizations:

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: Select one of the pre-define time intervals to zoom in to the chart, or drag an area of the chart with your mouse you want to zoom in to.

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: Select an individual position or group (i.e. an individual row) from the table to re-draw the return graph for the selected position or group.

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: Select multiple positions or groups to re-draw the return graph for comparison.

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: Click a point in the return graph to re-draw the allocation pie to show the selected day's allocation.

title: Export time series of data
body: Analytics+ provides you with tools to export time series of underlying data from Analytics+. This provides you with means to figure out how different figures are calculated in Analytics+ and how the underlying data has changed over time. You can also use the exported time series to further enrich your data, for example to apply further calculations in a spreadsheet or turn the time series into diagrams. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Export time series of data
body: Right-click your selection in Analytics+ and choose to Export time series of all underlying data as XLSX or Export time series of TWR-related data as XLSX. Exports contain:

title: Export time series of data
body: Time series of the selected data based on your selected date range, each day’s values on its own row.

title: Export time series of data
body: All underlying data available in Analytics+ or TWR-related data with relevant formulas for you to track how TWR was calculated each day.

title: Export time series of data
body: Each time series on its on sheet in the Excel, if you multi-selected rows before taking the export.

title: Export time series of data
body: The time series export does not export the columns you have selected in Analytics+ nor the values shown in Analytics+ columns - the time series export exports the time series of the underlying "raw" data that Analytics+ uses to calculate the figures it shows, such as TWR % for a specific time period.

title: Export time series of data
body: You can flexibly export different data sets through selecting different levels in your analysis. You can export data for individual positions, for any available group level (e.g. “Stocks” or “Funds”), or for total “Investments”. Select different portfolios or groups to aggregate data, different groupings to gain new levels to export data from, and different time periods to control the length of your time series.

title: Figures available in Analytics
body: The tables below list the main measurements and formulas available in Analytics+. In addition to the below described measures, different time periods (1, 3, 6, 12 months and year-to-date (YTD)) are available for certain key ratios. In addition, you can select Code and Name.

title: Figures available in Analytics
body: Logarithmic (natural) returns are used as a input in most of the calculations.

title: Figures available in Analytics
body: New columns are added into Analytics+ in each version - if you are running an older version of FA, you might not have all the below columns available. Refer to the Release notes for when new values are introduced.

title: Risk-adjusted performance measures
body: Risk-adjusted measures listed below makes it easier to compare different assets, portfolios and securities. Different to basic performance measures, these measures take also into consideration the riskiness of the investment.

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Certain key ratios are available also for benchmark (identified with "Bm" at the end of the column name).

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: There is a specific logic to determine which benchmark is used in which scenario:

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Portfolio's benchmark (if it exists) is always used on the portfolio level, when:

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: investments are grouped by portfolio

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: the analysis is taken on a single portfolio

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: If portfolio has a benchmark that a) is composed of one or many instruments (usually indices) and b) instrument is linked to a sector that is used in the grouping of the analysis => that instrument is used as a benchmark for the sector

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Otherwise, if the sector has a default benchmark defined in Preferences - Asset classes and types => that benchmark is used as a benchmark for the sector

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Benchmark aggregation is also supported up or down the grouping selected for the analysis with the following conditions:

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Benchmarks are aggregated up if the parent does not have its own benchmark (e.g. sector benchmarks are summed up with weighted daily average of TWR Bm to the parent group and sub-portfolio benchmarks are summed up to the main portfolio if sub-portfolios are included in the grouping). If the parent portfolio has content, it will be considered one of the child portfolios in analytics+ when using "Portfolio and subportfolio" grouping. Therefore, the aggregation logic works only if the parent portfolio is empty.

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Aggregated values never replace actual values (e.g. sector benchmarks or sub-portfolio benchmarks are not aggregated to portfolio, if the portfolio has its own benchmark).

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Benchmarks are aggregated down as well (e.g. sector benchmark is used in instruments under the sector benchmarks). However, this does not apply to the portfolio benchmark. only to sector benchmarks.

title: Add a column based on a key figure
body: You can add custom columns based on key figures into the different search views and Analytics+. To learn how to do this, follow the instructions below.

title: Add a column based on a key figure
body: If the key figure you want to add as an Analytics+ column isn't already in the system, configure it in Preference first. To learn how to add key figures, see Add key figures in FA User guide.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: You can add key figure values for contacts, portfolios, or securities by entering them manually in the respective windows or by importing them.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: Open the Key figures tab in the Contact, Portfolio, or Security window.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: On the left side of the tab, select the key figure and click Add new value.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: Define the date and value.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: Click Add.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: For more information about importing key figures, see File formats for importing securities and security prices and File formats for importing contacts, addresses and portfolios in FA Back reference.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: To configure a key figure as an Analytics+ column, do the following:

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Open Preference → Content and translations → Analytics+ columns.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Click Add new column and fill in the fields:

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Select how you want to define the column - Select "Based on a security key figure".

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Code* - A unique code for the column. You can't change the code after saving.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Name* - Name for the column.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Description - Optional description of the column content, shown when selecting columns in Analytics+.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Link - Optional link for more information about the column, shown when selecting columns in Analytics+.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Select the security key figure you want to use as a column - Choose the key figure to link to the column from the dropdown list.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Select how to calculate values on group levels -

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Do you want to override the default formatting? Choose if you want to specify a custom formatting for the column. If you select "Yes, override formatting", you also need to specify the format.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Click Save.

title: Unlock contact's portfolios when LEI is entered
body: This rule removes the "LEI code missing" portfolio tag and unlocks the contact's portfolios if the contact has LEI code entered in the Contact window, MiFiR tab.

title: API integrations
body: GraphiQL is a query tool available in FA Developer App. The tool can be used to define queries and mutations. It features a GraphQL editor, as well as documentation for the available GraphQL endpoints.

title: API integrations
body: GraphQL API provides many customization opportunities, for example:

title: API integrations
body: Building an integration between FA and an external application. A good example of this would be an integration between FA and your version of FA Client Portal.

title: API integrations
body: Building a custom JSReport (for details about custom reports, see the Reporting section). JSReports use GraphQL API to fetch the report data from FA Back.

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app
body: The GraphQL API view provides you access to the GraphiQL client to run queries and mutations to the FA GraphQL API.

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app
body: The menu on the left shows the GraphQL endpoints you can access:

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app
body: Portfolio management (/graphql)

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app
body: Fund management (/services/fund/graphql)

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app
body: Type in the query and get the response on the right. Use the buttons at the top to toggle the display of panes:

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app
body: Explorer

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app
body: The list of objects and fields to choose from for constructing a query.

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app
body: History

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app
body: The queries you executed.

title: Import and modify data via mutation API
body: Import and modify data via mutation API

title: Overview
body: You can import or modify FA data via GraphQL mutation API. When you import an object (for example, a contact or a portfolio), you need to provide all required fields as a parameter. When modifying an object you need to give minimum information that is enough to identify the entity. Imported attributes are updated, the left out attributes keep their previous values.

title: Overview
body: To import or modify different object types, use the following endpoints:

title: Overview
body: Contacts => importContacts

title: Overview
body: Portfolios => importPortfolios

title: Overview
body: Securities => importSecurities

title: Overview
body: Transactions => importTransactions

title: Overview
body: Trade orders => importTradeOrders

title: Overview
body: Security prices => importPrices

title: Overview
body: You can adjust the import behavior by using importGeneral endpoint and specifying the import parameters as you need. The import parameters are listed below:

title: Overview
body: importGeneral:

title: Overview
body: rows : list of objects to import (mandatory)

title: Overview
body: withRules : boolean whether to run rules when importing (default = false)

title: Overview
body: importAsync : boolean whether to use asynchronous importing or not (default = false)

title: Overview
body: mode / sMode / pMode / prMode / trMode / oMode / cMode : option to control import behavior for all object types (mode) or specific object type (sMode / pMode / prMode / trMode / oMode / cMode). Available options are:

title: Overview
body: 0 - insert and update (default)

title: Overview
body: 1- insert only

title: Overview
body: 2 - update only

title: Overview
body: Each endpoint can be used to import or update one or many objects in one request. The response identifies if the request was successful or if it had errors (specified in the response).

title: Define the request
body: For a valid request such as below, you need to:

title: Define the request
body: Define the mutation endpoint to use.

title: Define the request
body: Define all required fields as attributes, as described in FA importing formats. In the request below, for example, the required fields for importing contacts are "Contact ID", "Name", "Type", "Juridical form", "Status", "Tax country", "Classification", and "Identity" (see FA Format for importing contacts in FA Back reference).

title: Define the request
body: You need to define the request content as a list in the parameter with the syntax from FA importing (see Importing in FA Back reference). However, you need to define the attributes without the prefix used in FA importing. For example, in FA importing, contact name is defined as "c.name", so in the mutation API, you need to define this attribute as "name".

title: Define the request
Define the request
body: You can find an example of how to use importGeneral to control whether to run rules in Import data and trigger a business rule.

title: Interpret the response
body: The response structure is similar to the request. The result contains a list of map structures. Each item in the list presents an object that was imported. All attributes including the ones not explicitly used in the request are returned. The attributes are prefixed. For example, contact name is c.name. The success is indicated in the importStatus attribute with the OK value.

title: Interpret the response
body:
{
  "data": {
    "importContacts": [
      {
        "c.marketingCommunication": "",
        "c.subType": "",
        "c.language": "",
        "c.type": "1",
        "c.taxCountry": "FI",
        "c.externalId": "",

        "c.representatives": "*** ,",
        "c.fax": "",
        "c.email": "",
        "c.extContactIdList": "",
        "c.name": "GraphQL contact",
        "c.status": "A",
        "c.profileAttributes": "",
        "c.classification3": "",
        "c.contactExchanges": "",

        "c.electronicCommunication": "",

}

title: Interpret the response
body: If required attributes are missing or the code is incorrect, the importStatus attribute has the ERROR value. Each attribute with an error is marked with ERROR (ERROR:[ImportError.required] in case the required value is missing).

title: Create a form
body: To create a form in FA Developer app, do the following:

title: Create a form
body: Go to Workflows → Forms and click Add form in the top right.

title: Create a form
body: Add components from the list on the left and define the component properties.

title: Create a form
body: Add a Label in the Display tab to distinguish the component from others. This field is required for some components.

title: Create a form
body: Specify the Property Name in the API tab to identify the field in the collected data for the component (see Define form components to import data in FA).

title: Create a form
body: For the Content component, enclose the text in HTML tags. Form translations only work for text inside HTML tags.

title: Create a form
body: Define the form name and save the form.

title: Create a form
body: After saving the form, you can see it in the Forms view. You can now use the form in a process: see Display a form.

title: Related links
body: Workflows

title: Handle position and account interest
body: You can use the FA system to calculate, track, and capitalize account interest for fund portfolio positions and cash accounts. The system calculates accrued interest every time you calculate NAV or fees if you set up a separate fee workflow (see Ongoing fees).

title: Handle position and account interest
body: The following sections describe how you can handle account interest for fund portfolio holdings and fund cash accounts, including how to capitalize accrued account interest.

title: Calculate accrued interest on fund portfolio positions
body: Accrued interest on the fund portfolio holdings is calculated automatically based on the fixings information entered for securities in FA Back. To learn more, see Bonds in FA User guide.

title: Calculate accrued interest on fund portfolio positions
body: You can track the accrual for fund portfolio holdings in the NAV overview in the "Accrued interest" row (see View and check NAV calculation).

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: The system uses the following formula to calculate accrued account interest:

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: Accrued interest

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: Account balance

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: Base interest rate

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: spread

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: Number of days in a year

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: In this formula, account balance is the balance at the beginning of the day, base interest rate is determined by an index or a fixed or floating rate, and spread is interest on top of the base rate that you can specify depending on the account balance.

title: Set up account interest
body: To set up account interest for a fund, you need to specify the account interest details by doing the following:

title: Set up account interest
body: In the NAV status view, click on the fund to open the side pane and then open the Fund wizard by clicking the icon.

title: Set up account interest
body: In the Basic info tab, select a cash account, click on Interest details, and fill in the fields. For field descriptions, see Basic info tab.

title: Set up account interest
body: Click Save.

title: Set up account interest
body: The system now starts accruing interest on the account. You can track the accrual in the NAV overview in the "Accrued account interest" row (see View and check NAV calculation).

title: Capitalize accrued interest in FA Back
body: To capitalize the interest accrued by fund investments, follow the instructions in steps 2 and 3 in Set up and run account interest (FA User guide). You can skip step 1 because fund account interest is already set up.

title: Capitalize accrued interest in FA Back
body: The system creates the capitalization transaction when you execute the account interest run. You can also schedule the run for later.

title: View funds and share classes
body: The NAV status view shows the list of your funds with key information, NAV status and dates, and outstanding trade orders.

title: View the list of funds
body: The NAV status view shows your funds and their share classes in a tree structure. For detailed column descriptions, see Fund and share class information. To view a fund group, choose one in the Select a fund group dropdown. The dropdown shows fund groups that have a code with the prefix "FAFUNDS_" (see Create fund groups in FA Back reference). You can see fund share classes under each fund in the list. In the NAV status view, you can also:

title: View the list of funds
body: Save a view you created by clicking .

title: View the list of funds
body: Restore the view by clicking .

title: View the list of funds
body: Manage saved views by clicking . In the side pane, you can set a view as the default by clicking .

title: View the list of funds
body: Refresh the list by clicking in the top right.

title: View the list of funds
body: Export the list of funds as an XLSX or CSV file.

title: View the list of funds
body: For the whole list, clickExport→Download as CSV/XLSX.

title: View the list of funds
body: For parts of the list, select rows and clickExport→Download as CSV/XLSX.

title: View fund details
body: To view the fund details, click the fund in the list and open the Fund details pane on the right. You can see:

title: View fund details
body: Basic info: fund ID and fund currency.

title: View fund details
body: NAV information: NAV status, next NAV date, who and when calculated and accepted the current NAV. If the NAV acceptance is in progress, you can view the details by clicking View progress.

title: View fund details
body: Orders: outstanding trade orders per share class affecting the next NAV calculation.

title: View fund details
body: For details about each field, see Fund and share class information.

title: View fund details
body: You can open the fund portfolio in FA Back by clicking View in FA Back .

title: View share class details
body: To view share class details, click on a share class in the list. In the Share class details pane, you can see the following information:

title: View share class details
body: Basic info: share class security information (Code, ISIN code, Currency), NAV data (Latest NAV as well as the NAV overview graph) and high-water mark information (if applicable).

title: View share class details
body: Orders: outstanding trade orders for the share class affecting the next NAV calculation.

title: View share class details
body: For the field descriptions, see Fund and share class information.

title: View share class details
body: You can open the share class security in FA Back by clicking View in FA Back .

title: Fund and share class information
body: ID

title: Fund and share class information
body: Portfolio ID for funds and Security code for share classes.

title: Fund and share class information
body: Status

title: Fund and share class information
body: NAV calculation status that indicates if you should calculate NAV for the fund today. Learn more about the statuses in the Workflows and NAV statuses section. NAV statuses are shown for the current date and time, displayed above the funds list. If the date and time aren’t current, refresh the page by clicking the refresh icon at the top-right corner to view the recent information.

title: Fund and share class information
body: Error

title: Fund and share class information
body: Errors in NAV calculation and acceptance. If there are any errors, you can see the icon next to the fund status. To view the errors, hover the mouse over the icon. To find out the error details, go to the audit log in the Fund details pane on the right.

title: Fund and share class information
body: Next NAV

title: Fund and share class information
body: The date for which you should calculate and accept NAV next. NAV date may differ from the calculation date – the date when you should do the calculation.

title: Fund and share class information
body: For example, you might calculate NAV for the last day of the month (for example, 31.1) on the first day of the next month (for example, 1.2). When you log in on 1.2 your fund status would be “pending NAV”, but the next NAV date would show 31.1.

title: Fund and share class information
body: The date switches to the next one in the schedule as soon as you accept the calculated NAV.

title: Fund and share class information
body: Latest NAV

title: Fund and share class information
body: The latest date for which you calculated and accepted NAV. You can see the corresponding NAV values on the share class level in the list.

title: Fund and share class information
body: NAV value

title: Fund and share class information
body: The latest calculated NAV value.

title: Fund and share class information
body: Order count, Total count

title: Fund and share class information
body: The number of outstanding trade orders on the fund level and for each share class. The number is based on the trade orders marked as executable in FA Back. To learn more about entering trade orders for the fund, see FA Back.

title: Fund and share class information
body: Order value, Total value

title: Fund and share class information
body: The value of outstanding trade orders. The calculation depends on how the trade order was entered in FA Back:

title: Fund and share class information
body: If the trade orders are based on the trade amount, Order value shows total net value. It is shown on the share class level and on the fund level, if all fund share classes are in the same currency.

title: Fund and share class information
body: If the trade orders are based on the number of units, Order value shows total number estimated with latest NAV: Order_value=Number_of_units⋅Latest_NAVOrder_value=Number_of_units\cdotLatest_NAV

title: NAV formula
body: FA Fund Management calculates NAV as the total value of cash and securities in a fund's portfolio (Gross asset value, GAV) deducted by the fund’s fees and divided by the number of outstanding units. The number of outstanding units is based on the executed trade orders (pending subscriptions aren't included).

title: Gross asset value (GAV)
body: Gross asset value of the fund or a share class is calculated based on the following items:

title: Gross asset value (GAV)
body: Market value of investments

title: Gross asset value (GAV)
body: Accrued interest on interest-bearing instruments, such as bonds

title: Gross asset value (GAV)
body: Accrued interest on cash accounts

title: Gross asset value (GAV)
body: Settled account balance (the balance calculated based on settled transactions)

title: Gross asset value (GAV)
body: Receivables from unsettled dividends, coupons and security sells

title: Gross asset value (GAV)
body: Liabilities from unsettled security purchases (deducted)

title: Gross asset value (GAV)
body: Accrued receivables from custom formulas.

title: Fund class share
body: In a fund with multiple share classes, the fund portfolio is divided between the share classes based on the previous unit price and the number of outstanding units.

title: Fund class share
body: The share of the fund portfolio belonging to share class is then calculated as:
