title: Set up a management fee
body: Example: The yearly management fee is 0,1%. The fund's previous NAV is 365 000 EUR. The used day count convention is "ACT/ACT ISDA" and the selected holiday calendar is "Saturday/Sunday weekends". The calculated fee is 365 000 EUR * 0,1% / 365 days * 1 day = 1 EUR. If we change the holiday calendar to "No holidays/weekends", the fee is calculated for all three days and amounts to 3 EUR.

title: Set up a management fee
body: To define a management fee for a fund or a share class, you need to:

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Fee formulas in FA Fund Management determine the calculation parameters. You can choose one of the pre-made configurations or create your own formula if the existing ones don't suit you.

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Available management fee formulas are:

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: To create your own fee formula:

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Open the NAV status view, click the gear icon in the top-right and choose Fee formulas.

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Click Add formula and fill in the fields:

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Formula name

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: The name of the formula. You will see it when you choose the fee formula in the fund or share class settings.

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Code

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: The formula code to identify the fee formula in the system.

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Fee type

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Fee type. Select "Management fee".

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Transaction type

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Transaction type to use for the fee accrual: choose "Management fee (MFEE)".

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Create daily transactions

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Create a fee transaction for each day of the calculation period (by default, FA Fund Management creates one summed fee transaction per calculation period).

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Day count

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: The day count convention to define the number of days in a year.

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Calculation base

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: NAV to use for the fee calculation: previous (for the previous period) or current (newly calculated).

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Exclude cash in base

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Exclude account balances when calculating the average market value. By default, all account balances are included.

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Description

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Fee formula description.

title: Choose or create a fee formula
body: Save the changes.

title: Add the fee to the fee structure
body: The next step is to include the fee in your fund's fee structure. You can apply the management fee on the fund or on the share class level. Fund-level fees are applied to all share classes. They are calculated first, in the order you place them in the fund settings, followed by the share class fees.

title: Add the fee to the fee structure
body: To define the fee parameters:

title: Add the fee to the fee structure
body: In the fund settings:

title: Add the fee to the fee structure
body: Set the fee capitalization account for the fund in the Basic info tab. Enable Set as fee capitalization account for the cash account you want to use for fee capitalization. You can only set one account for fee capitalization per fund. If you do not set a fee capitalization account, the system uses the account you marked as the default account in the Basic info tab.

title: Add the fee to the fee structure
body: (Optional) If you want to use a separate schedule for calculating fees ( see Ongoing fees for details), set it up in the Schedules tab.

title: Add the fee to the fee structure
body: Define the fee crystallization schedule in the Schedules tab. For details about schedule settings, see Create a fund.

title: Add the fee to the fee structure
body: Add the management fee on the fund or share class level. Open the Fee structure tab in the fund or share class settings, add the fee formula, percentage and other parameters (for details about fee parameters, see Create a fund and Add share classes). Select Use crystallization schedule for capitalization in Additional options.

title: Add the fee to the fee structure
body: After you set up the fee calculation and capitalization, FA Fund Management creates accrued fee transactions every time you calculate NAV. On the fee capitalization date, the fee amount is transferred from the cash account to the accrued fees account when you accept NAV.

title: About FA Advisor
body: FA Advisor app provides advisors with tools for managing customer-related tasks and onboarding new customers. You can use FA Advisor to do the following:

title: About FA Advisor
body: Work with customers

title: About FA Advisor
body: Maintain up-to-date customer information. You can view your customers, or all customers in the system, and select an individual customer to view and edit their details.

title: About FA Advisor
body: Add customer-related notes and store documents.

title: About FA Advisor
body: Manage customer-related tasks: calls, emails, letters, meetings, or custom tasks that you define.

title: About FA Advisor
body: Onboard new customers.

title: About FA Advisor
body: Manage customer investments

title: About FA Advisor
body: View a summary of a customer's investments or see more details in FA Client Portal.

title: About FA Advisor
body: Trade for the customer via FA Client Portal.

title: About FA Advisor
body: Keep track of unsigned trade orders that the customer needs to accept.

title: User access
body: Users of FA Advisor need the correct rights to access the app and its functionalities such as trading on behalf of customers.

title: Access to FA Advisor
body: To access FA Advisor, a user needs the correct rights in FA Admin Console. To provide a user access to FA Advisor, do the following:

title: Access to FA Advisor
body: Ensure the FA Advisor application is enabled. Contact FA if you need to enable it.

title: Access to FA Advisor
body: In FA Admin Console, assign the user the ROLE_USER right within the FA Advisor role (see Access to FA functionality in FA Admin guide).

title: Access to FA Advisor
body: If limited visibility is in use, it also applies to FA Advisor and the user can see the same customers as in FA Back (see Access for employees in FA Admin guide).

title: Access to trading via FA Client Portal
body: To trade on behalf of customers in FA Advisor, a user needs to have the rights to impersonate customers in FA Client Portal. To provide a user the rights, do the following:

title: Access to trading via FA Client Portal
body: Make sure the user has access to FA Advisor (see Access to FA Advisor).

title: Access to trading via FA Client Portal
body: In FA Admin Console, assign the user the following rights (see Access to FA functionality in FA Admin guide):

title: Access to trading via FA Client Portal
body: ROLE_CLIENT_PORTAL_IMPERSONATE within the FA Back role.

title: Access to trading via FA Client Portal
body: ROLE_IMPERSONATE within the FA Client Portal role.

title: Access to trading via FA Client Portal
body: The user can now access a customer's investments via FA Client Portal and trade on their behalf. A banner at the top of the view shows what the user has the rights to do with green checkmarks (buy, sell, switch, deposit, withdraw, and cancel orders).

title: Work with customers
body: FA Advisor enables you to access customer profiles in the FA Platform to work with your customers. Customer profiles are created in FA Back as contacts, and FA Advisor allows you to maintain up-to-date information about a customer as well as manage tasks, documents, and notes related to them.

title: View and edit customer information
body: The Customers view gives you an overview of customers. You can:

title: View and edit customer information
body: Use the Customer group drop-down to view only customers you are linked to as a representative (default) or to view all customers in the system.

title: View and edit customer information
body: Filter, sort and select columns to view with the icons above the table. You can also save a view you created and open it again later by clicking Save view. To manage saved views or set a saved view as the default, click .

title: View and edit customer information
body: Export the list as a CSV file or print it by clicking the Export button.

title: View and edit customer information
body: Open customer details by clicking  in the Actions column.

title: View and edit customer information
body: Access a customer's investments through FA Client Portal app. You can view their investments or trade for them by clicking  in the Actions column.

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: You can see the following information as columns in the Customers view or fields in the Customer details:

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Address (Address 1, Address 2, Postal code, City, Country)

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Customer’s address information.

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Advisors

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Customer's advisors (contacts with contact type 2 in FA Back). You can edit contact definitions under contact type 2 in FA Back (Preference → Contacts → Contact types).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Cash

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Amount of cash in portfolios where the customer is the main contact. The value is shown in the portfolio currency.

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Classification

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Trading classification of the customer, for example, professional or non-professional. Classification can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit it in FA Back (Contact window).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Customer ID

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Unique ID defined for a customer in FA Back. Customer ID can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit it in FA Back (Contact ID in Contact window).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Customer type

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Contact type specified in FA Back. Customer type can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit it in FA Back (Contact window, Type field).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Date of birth

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Customer's date of birth.

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Email

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Email address of the customer.

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: External ID

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Customer ID in an external system, for example, identity number or social security number. The external ID can be used to set up client authentication in the FA Platform.

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Identity

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Identity format of the customer, for example passport. Identity can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit it in FA Back (Contact window).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Investments

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Amount of investments, excluding cash, in portfolios where the customer is the main contact. The value is shown in the portfolio currency.

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Juridical form

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Juridical form of the customer, for example, private person or company. Juridical form can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit it in FA Back (Contact window).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Language

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Language of reports for the customer. If no language is selected, the reports are printed out in Finnish. Language can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit it in FA Back (Contact window).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Name

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Name of the customer.

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Nationality

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Nationality of the customer. Nationality can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit it in FA Back (Contact window).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Order status

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Trade order status. If the customer has unsigned trade orders, the column shows "Unsigned trade orders".

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Phone numbers 1 and 2

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Customer's phone numbers.

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Represented by

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Persons who represent the customer and the tags specified for them in the customer profile. Representatives can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can add representatives in FA Back (see Representatives in FA Back reference).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Represents

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Persons the customer represents and optional tags assigned to them. Representatives can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit representatives in FA Back (see Representatives in FA Back reference).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Status

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Status of the customer record in the system (active, passive, or closed). Customer status can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit it in FA Back (Contact window).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Tags

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Tags assigned to the customer in the system. Tags are used, for example, to set up access to customer portfolios, manage trade orders, or produce reports. Tags can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit them in FA Back (Contact window).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Taxation country

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Taxation country of the customer. Taxation country can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit it in FA Back (Contact window).

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Total assets

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Combined amount of cash and investments in portfolios where the customer is the main contact. The value is shown in the portfolio currency.

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Transaction no. level

title: Customer information in FA Advisor views
body: Level at which the system generates transaction numbers. This is either the portfolio level where the transaction number is individual to each transaction within the portfolio, or the contact level where the transaction number is individual to each transaction within all of the contact's portfolios. Transaction no. level can't be edited in FA Advisor. You can edit it in FA Back (Contact window).

title: Add notes and documents
body: The Notes section at the bottom of Customer details view allows you to add your customer-related notes, store documents like agreements or investment plans, and maintain meeting notes about customer meetings. If the customer has a contact memo in FA Back, you can see it in FA Advisor.

title: Add notes and documents
body: To display notes in FA Advisor correctly, we recommend you use, for example, Google Chrome or Safari as your browser.

title: Manage notes
body: You can add notes related to the customer in the Customer info tab or add new tabs. Notes are also shown in FA Back Contact window, Documents tab. If you delete a note in FA Back, it is also deleted from FA Advisor.

title: Manage notes
body: The FA Back note tab shows the contact memo from the Contact window in FA Back, if you previously used it to store information about the customers. You can't edit or delete the memo directly in FA Advisor.

title: Manage notes
body: To add a new tab with a note, do the following:

title: Manage notes
body: Click + Add tab and enter a name for the note.

title: Manage notes
body: Add note content in the text editor.

title: Manage notes
body: Click Save.

title: Manage meeting notes
body: The Meeting notes tab allows you to add notes about meetings and link them to specific dates. Meeting notes are also shown in FA Back Contact window, Documents tab. If you delete a meeting note in FA Back, it is also deleted from FA Advisor.

title: Manage meeting notes
body: To add a meeting note, do the following:

title: Manage meeting notes
body: Click Add meeting note. Create a blank note or select a template (templates are uploaded in FA Back, see Upload meeting note templates for FA Advisor in FA Admin guide).

title: Manage meeting notes
body: Enter a name and date for the note and add content in the text editor.

title: Manage meeting notes
body: Click Save.

title: Store documents
body: In the Documents tab, you can see documents uploaded for the customer. You can track the signing status and check the FA Client Portal availability of each document. To add documents, do the following:

title: Store documents
body: Click Upload and add the documents.

title: Store documents
body: Fill in the fields: Category, Signing status, Show in FA Client Portal. See the field descriptions below.

title: Store documents
body: Click Upload.

title: Store documents
body: To edit the category, signing status, or availability in FA Client Portal for an uploaded document, click in the Actions column.

title: Store documents
body: You can see the following information for each document:

title: Store documents
body: Category

title: Store documents
body: Document category, for example, agreement or investment plan. Document categories are defined as tags under "Document type" in FA Back (Preference → Tags → Document tags).

title: Store documents
body: Document name

title: Store documents
body: The file name. The supported file types are: PDF, DOC, DOCX, ODT, XLS, XLSX, PPT, PPTX, ODP, ODS, TXT, CSV, XML, PNG, JPG, RTF, and MP3.

title: Store documents
body: Uploaded by

title: Store documents
body: The user ID of the user who uploaded the document.

title: Store documents
body: Upload date

title: Store documents
body: The upload date and time of the document.

title: Store documents
body: Signing status

title: Store documents
body: Document signing status: canceled, done, error, expired, pending or waiting. These document signing statuses are included in FA Standard Solution, otherwise statuses are defined in FA Back in Preference → Tags → Document tags under "Document signing". Documents are sent for signing in FA Back (see Document signing in User guide).

title: Store documents
body: FA Client Portal

title: Store documents
body: Document availability to customer in FA Client Portal, indicated with a checkmark. You can make a document available when uploading by ticking the Show in FA Client Portal checkbox. In FA Back, documents that are available in FA Client Portal are assigned the tag "Online" (included in FA Standard Solution, otherwise the tag is defined in Preference → Tags → Document tags).

title: Manage tasks
body: Tasks allow you to plan and record your actions when communicating with a customer. You can schedule calls, emails, letters, and meetings and make notes related to them. You can create other task types in the FA Developer app (see Workflows in FA Developer guide). When a task is done, you can mark it as completed. The following sections describe how you can add tasks, search for tasks, and mark tasks as completed.

title: Add a task
body: You can add a new task related to a customer by doing the following:

title: Add a task
body: In the Customer details, Open tasks section, click Add task and select the task type (call, email or letter, meeting). Alternatively, you can click Add task in the Tasks view and select the customer the task is related to after choosing the task type.

title: Add a task
body: Fill in the task information. You can also mark the task as completed.

title: Add a task
body: Click Save.

title: Work on tasks
body: When working with a customer, you can see open tasks related to them by going to the Customer details and viewing the Open tasks section. To view and manage all tasks assigned to you or any other user, go to the Tasks view. The Tasks view allows you to do the following:

title: Work on tasks
body: Search for tasks based on assignee, task type, and task status.

title: Work on tasks
body: View only tasks assigned to you by selecting "Assigned to me" in the Assignee filter.

title: Work on tasks
body: View and manage the task information by clicking in the Actions column.

title: Work on tasks
body: In the side pane that opens, you can change the task status by editing the Due date (future due date gives the task "Open" status, while past due date gives the task "Overdue" status) or by marking the task as complete.

title: Task information
body: The following information is available for tasks:

title: Task information
body: Assignee

title: Task information
body: The user the task is assigned to.

title: Task information
body: Customer

title: Task information
body: The name of the customer.

title: Task information
body: Creator

title: Task information
body: The user who created the task.

title: Task information
body: Due date

title: Task information
body: The date by which the task needs to be completed.

title: Task information
body: Note

title: Task information
body: Notes about the task.

title: Task information
body: Status

title: Task information
body: Task status ("Open", "Overdue", or "Completed"). The "Overdue" status is applied to tasks with a due date in the past. The "Completed" status is applied to tasks marked as complete.

title: Task information
body: Task type

title: Task information
body: Type of action. Standard task types are call, email or letter, and meeting.

title: Mark a task as complete
body: After finishing a task, you can mark it as completed by doing the following:

title: Mark a task as complete
body: Click the icon in the Actions column of a task to open the side pane.

title: Mark a task as complete
body: Tick the checkbox Mark task as completed.

title: Mark a task as complete
body: Click Save.

title: Mark a task as complete
body: The task status changes to "Completed".

title: Manage customer's investments
body: You can view a summary of customer investments in FA Advisor. You can also create trade orders on behalf of the customer via FA Client Portal. Trade orders are sent for execution after the customer signs them.

title: View customer's investments
body: In the Customer details, you can view a summary of a customer's investments in the Investments section. You can view the investment summary for the customer's active portfolios in the following ways:

title: View customer's investments
body: As a table by clicking . The table shows the portfolio name, ID, currency, and in the portfolio currency the value (existing holdings and executed amount) of securities, cash accounts, and market value. The portfolios are in alphabetical order by default, but you can sort the columns in ascending or descending order.

title: View customer's investments
body: As a pie chart by clicking , but only if the customer's portfolios are all in the same currency. The pie chart shows the name, ID, and total value of active portfolios. Portfolios with less than 5% of the total value are grouped together. If the customer has more than 10 portfolios in the same currency, the pie chart displays 9 portfolios and the remaining portfolios are grouped together.

title: View customer's investments
body: You can also access the customer's investments via FA Client Portal in the following ways:

title: View customer's investments
body: In the Customer details view, click Open FA Client Portal in the top right.

title: View customer's investments
body: Open the Customers view and click the icon in the Actions column.

title: Trade via FA Client Portal
body: You can buy, sell, or switch securities and make deposits and withdrawals on behalf of the customer via FA Client Portal. When making trade orders on behalf of the customer, you can also send them to be signed by the customer before execution.

title: Trade via FA Client Portal
body: You can only trade via FA Client Portal with portfolios in the group "ADV_TRADING" and securities in groups that start with "ADV_.". The groups are assigned in FA Back (see Security groups and Portfolio groups in FA Back reference).

title: Trade via FA Client Portal
body: To trade on behalf of a customer, do the following:

title: Trade via FA Client Portal
body: In the Customers view, click the icon in the Actions column. Alternatively, click Open FA Client Portal in the top right of the Customer details. The customer's FA Client Portal opens.

title: Trade via FA Client Portal
body: Make sure you have the rights to trade in the banner at the top of the view (see User access). Allowed actions have a green check mark next to them.

title: Trade via FA Client Portal
body: Make the trade order, deposit, or withdrawal. For information on how to make trade orders, deposits, and withdrawals, see FA Client Portal documentation.

title: Trade via FA Client Portal
body: The trade order you created is tagged with "Advisor" in FA Back and has the pending signing status until the customer signs it. The customer's Status column in the Customers view now shows "Unsigned trade orders".

title: Cancel a trade order
body: You can cancel trade orders in the customer's FA Client Portal app. For details on how to cancel trade orders, see Orders view in FA Client Portal.

title: View pending trade orders
body: If a customer has pending trade orders waiting for acceptance, you can see an indicator in the following places:

title: View pending trade orders
body: Customers view, Status column: Shows "Unsigned trade orders".

title: View pending trade orders
body: Customer details: Shows a bell icon next to the customer's name at the top of the view. Hovering your mouse over the bell icon shows the unsigned trade orders from the oldest to the newest.

title: View pending trade orders
body: You can use these indicators to keep track of customers who need to be contacted, for example.

title: Scheduling
body: You can configure FA processes to run at specific times. The scheduling is done with Cron expressions.

title: Scheduling
body: If you have overlapping schedules, the system shows a warning. Five scheduled processes can run at the same time, but overlapping runs can cause issues if they affect the same data. For example, we don't recommend generating settlement and payment instructions for the same transactions simultaneously.

title: Create, edit and remove schedules
body: To create and manage schedules, open Tools → Administer → Scheduled functions in the top menu. After selecting a scheduled process, you can see the Cron schedule specified for it. This means a regular execution time has been set for the process.

title: Create, edit and remove schedules
body: To add a new schedule:

title: Create, edit and remove schedules
body: Click the Add button and fill in the fields:

title: Create, edit and remove schedules
body: Cron schedule

title: Create, edit and remove schedules
body: The process schedule specified using Cron syntax (see Cron schedules). The next execution time is shown when a valid Cron schedule is entered.

title: Create, edit and remove schedules
body: Configuration

title: Create, edit and remove schedules
body: The configuration used for the schedule.

title: Create, edit and remove schedules
body: Saved views

title: Create, edit and remove schedules
body: The saved view, if it’s relevant for the process you are scheduling. The saved view can be e.g. saved transaction view if you are scheduling a functionality that runs against a list of transactions.

title: Create, edit and remove schedules
body: Click Save to save the schedules. Alternatively, you can click Remove to delete a schedule.

title: Create, edit and remove schedules
body: Click the Run button to test your configurations. The functionality is run with the configuration set and saved view you specified.

title: Cron schedules
body: The schedules are specified in the Cron syntax. The basic principles are:

title: Cron schedules
body: The schedules are specified in the following order, with space separating each component:

title: Cron schedules
body: Seconds

title: Cron schedules
body: Minutes

title: Cron schedules
body: Hours

title: Cron schedules
body: Day-of-month

title: Cron schedules
body: Month

title: Cron schedules
body: Day-of-week

title: Cron schedules
body: Year (optional)

title: Cron schedules
body: Asterisk ( * ) can be used to specify any value (for example, * as the Day-of-month component indicates that the schedule is run every day of the month).

title: Cron schedules
body: Question mark (?) can be used in day-of-month and day-of-week fields to specify “no specific value”.

title: Cron schedules
body: Some examples of different kinds of schedules:

title: Cron schedules
body: Daily at 15:00:

title: Cron schedules
body: On the first second of the first minute of the 15th hour, every day of month and every month, regardless of the day-of-week

title: Cron schedules
body: Every Friday at 12:30:

title: Cron schedules
body: Every weekday (Monday through Friday) at 08:10:20

title: Cron schedules
body: 20 10 08 ? * MON-FRI

title: Cron schedules
body: On the first day of every month at 21:00

title: Export list of schedules
body: You can export scheduled runs as an XLSX file. This can help you, for example, to determine how to add a new schedule with as little overlap as possible. To export a list of scheduled runs, do the following:

title: Export list of schedules
body: Go to Tools → Administer → Scheduled functions.

title: Export list of schedules
body: Click Export scheduled runs.

title: Export list of schedules
body: An XLSX file is downloaded to your computer. The file contains the process ID, cron expression, run time (for the next 24 hours and one run thereafter), configuration name, namespace, view type and view name.

title: Steps to set up contract preferences
body: Contracts provides you with an easy and efficient way for entering contract-type investments, such as FX contracts, into FA. Saving your contract saves it within your transactions, but also produces relevant positions into your portfolio and generates relevant cashflows for the end of the contract. Due to this, you need to configure certain preferences to start using contracts.

title: Step 1 - Create transaction types
body: First, set up relevant transaction types that are used to save the contract within your transactions, generate forward cashflow positions into your portfolio in the beginning of the contract, and generate relevant cashflows at the end of the contract. You can set these up in Transaction type Preferences.

title: Step 1 - Create transaction types
body: Configure a transaction type that is used for saving the contract into your portfolio. You need one transaction type for "Add contract". For more specifics, see Transaction types for contracts.

title: Step 1 - Create transaction types
body: Configure transaction types that are used for opening the forward cashflow positions into your portfolio in the beginning of the contract. You need separate transaction types for "Forward cashflow in" and "Forward cashflow out". For more specifics, see Transaction types for contracts.

title: Step 1 - Create transaction types
body: Configure transaction types that are used for saving the cashflows generated at the end of the contract. You need separate transaction types for "Cashflow in" and "Cashflow out". For more specifics, see Transaction types for contracts.For more specifics, see

title: Step 2 - Create security types and link transaction types to security types
body: Second, set up relevant security types that are used for creating the contract security and forward cashflow securities, and link the transaction types you created in step 1 to relevant security types. You can set these up in Security type Preferences:

title: Step 2 - Create security types and link transaction types to security types
body: Configure a security type that is used for creating the contract security for the contract. You can otherwise use any security type name, but you should use the base type CONTRACT. For more specifics, see Security types for contracts.

title: Step 2 - Create security types and link transaction types to security types
body: Link the "Add contract" transaction type you created in step 1.1 to your new contract security type you created in step 2.1

title: Step 2 - Create security types and link transaction types to security types
body: Configure a security type that is used for creating forward cashflow securities for the contract's forward cashflows. You can otherwise use any security type name, but you should use the base type DISCOUNT. For more specifics, see Security types for contracts.

title: Step 2 - Create security types and link transaction types to security types
body: Link the "Forward cashflow in",  "Forward cashflow out", "Cashflow in" and "Cashflow out" transaction types you created in steps 1.2 and 1.3 to your new forward cashflow security type you created in step 2.3. If you miss this step, your (forward) cashflow transactions are shown without a transaction type when you open them!

title: Step 3 - Configure contract types
body: Third, once you have relevant transaction types and security types in place, you can configure your contract types in Contract types Preferences. You need to separately configure each contract type you want to use by associating the transaction types and security types you created in step 1 and 2 to each contract type.

title: Step 3 - Configure contract types
body: Configure a new contract type to start setting up the configurations. You can configure each supported contract type only once - if the list is empty when configuring a new contract type, you have already configured all supported contract types!

title: Step 3 - Configure contract types
body: The available configurations vary a bit based on the contract type you selected. Each contract type results in a different number of items created when saving the contract - you can associate the following security types and transaction types to your contracts:

title: Step 3 - Configure contract types
body: Security type (e.g. "FX contract") and a transaction type (e.g. "Add contract") used to save the contract.

title: Step 3 - Configure contract types
body: Separate transaction types (e.g. "Cashflow in" and "Cashflow out") for "buy" and "sell" cashflows generated at the end of the contract.

title: Step 3 - Configure contract types
body: Security type (e.g. "Forward cashflow") and separate transaction types (e.g. "Forward cashflow in" and "Forward cashflow out") for "buy" and "sell" forward cashflows opened in the beginning of the contract.

title: Step 4 - Decide on additional contract preferences
body: Fourth, there are additional Contract preferences you should make a decision about (available from FA 3.7 onward). These preferences are not mandatory to change, but in order for your contracts to be created according to your liking, you should make a decision on these in the beginning. Also, changing these settings later on will not have an effect on the contracts you have already saved.

title: Step 5 - Configure yield curves for valuating your forward cashflows
body: For the system to be able to valuate the forward cashflow positions generated for your FX contracts, you need to configure appropriate discount curves in Yield curve Preferences. You need to have appropriate yield curves for all currencies involved in your FX contracts, and the yield curves are used to calculate the discount factors for each forward cashflow until maturity, and the discount factors are then used to calculate the net present value of your forward cashflows.

title: Step 5 - Configure yield curves for valuating your forward cashflows
body: For more details, see Steps to set up yield curves for valuating forward cashflows for valuating forward cashflows. Find below an overview of the required steps:

title: Step 5 - Configure yield curves for valuating your forward cashflows
body: Set up the interest rates (e.g. LIBOR EUR 1W, 1M, 2M, 3M, 6M and 12M) you want to use as points in your yield curve. You need at least two interest rates with different maturities for interpolation to work between them. Set up your interest rates as securities in the system (i.e. one security for each interest rate with different maturity). Set the tenor for you interest rate, and multipliers 100 and 100 if you are receiving your market data as "percentage rates" (i.e. market date entry 2,73 means interest rate 2,73 %).

title: Step 5 - Configure yield curves for valuating your forward cashflows
body: Set up yield curves (e.g. LIBOR EUR DISCOUNT) out of the interest rates you defined in step 1. You should set up a yield curve for each currency involved in you FX contracts. Set up your yield curves under the Yield curves preferences (i.e. one curve for each currency). Link your interest rates to your yield curve as securities, and select value type ZeroRate if your interest rate securities get their market data as interest rates.

title: Step 5 - Configure yield curves for valuating your forward cashflows
body: Create curve groups out of the yield curves you defined in step 2. Curve groups allow you to indicate which curve should be used to discount which currency.

title: Step 6 - Enable permissions for managing contracts
body: Enable permissions for managing contracts. Per each user role, you can separately define whether they have the permission to only view, modify and create, or delete contracts. In addition, you can separately control which users can import contracts.

title: Step 6 - Enable permissions for managing contracts
body: Once your permissions are in place, your users can start entering contracts into the system.

title: Steps to set up yield curves for valuating forward cashflows
body: In order for the system to be able to valuate the forward cashflow positions generated for your contracts, you need to have appropriate yield curves defined in the system for all currencies involved in your FX contracts. These discount curves are used to calculate the discount factors for each forward cashflow security until maturity, and the discount factors are then used to calculate the net present value of your forward cashflow on any historical date.

title: Step 1 - Create securities for the interest rates you want to use as points in your yield curve
body: First step is to set up the interest rates you want to use as points in your yield curve. You need at least two interest rates with different maturities for interpolation to work between them - however, you can add as many interest rates you'd like to use to build your curve. For example, you can set up interest rates for LIBOR EUR 1W, 1M, 2M, 3M, 6M and 12M.

title: Step 1 - Create securities for the interest rates you want to use as points in your yield curve
body: You can set up your interest rates as securities in the system (i.e. one security for each interest rate with different maturity). Set descriptive codes and names and an appropriate currency to the interest rate securities, and pay close attention to the following relevant configurations:

title: Step 1 - Create securities for the interest rates you want to use as points in your yield curve
body: Tenor

title: Step 1 - Create securities for the interest rates you want to use as points in your yield curve
body: Indicate which tenor the interest rate is associated with, i.e. the duration / maturity of the interest rate. You have a variety of options for days (D), weeks (W), months (M) and years (Y) - make sure the tenor corresponds with the interest rate you are defining. For example, for the rate "LIBOR EUR 1W" select tenor "1W" and for "LIBOR EUR 12M" select tenor "12M".

title: Step 1 - Create securities for the interest rates you want to use as points in your yield curve
body: Multipliers

title: Step 1 - Create securities for the interest rates you want to use as points in your yield curve
body: Often you receive the market data for your interest rates as "percentage rates" (i.e. market date entry 2,73 means interest rate 2,73 %). In order for all calculations to work with percentage values, set both Multiplier and Multiplier 2 to 100.

title: Step 1 - Create securities for the interest rates you want to use as points in your yield curve
body: Market data

title: Step 1 - Create securities for the interest rates you want to use as points in your yield curve
body: If you set both multipliers to 100, make sure your interest rates feed in as percentages. For valuation to work, make sure you get a daily interest rate feed for all the interest rates you have defined in the system and are planning to use in your yield curve - if an entry is missing from one of the interest rates for one date, the interest rate with that tenor is ignored for that date, and a value is interpolated from other existing interest rates instead.

title: Step 2 - Create a discount curve for each currency you want to valuate forward cashflows with
body: Second step is to set up yield curves out of the interest rates you defined in step 1. You should set up a yield curve for each currency involved in you FX contracts - if you want to valuate forward cashflows for the currency, you need to have a discount yield curve in place for the currency. For example, you can set up yield curves for LIBOR EUR DISCOUNT and LIBOR USD DISCOUNT.

title: Step 2 - Create a discount curve for each currency you want to valuate forward cashflows with
body: You can set up your yield curves under the Yield curves preferences (i.e. one curve for each currency). Set descriptive names to the curves, and pay close attention to the following relevant configurations:

title: Step 2 - Create a discount curve for each currency you want to valuate forward cashflows with
body: Security

title: Step 2 - Create a discount curve for each currency you want to valuate forward cashflows with
body: Add the interest rates you defined in step 1 as securities - the security and its tenor tells the yield curve where to fetch the points for each day when building the curve. The securities you link should have the appropriate tenor, and you should only add one security with the same tenor. You need at least two interest rate securities with different maturities for interpolation to work between them.

title: Step 2 - Create a discount curve for each currency you want to valuate forward cashflows with
body: Value type

title: Step 2 - Create a discount curve for each currency you want to valuate forward cashflows with
body: Select ZeroRate as the value type if your interest rate securities get their market data as interest rates.

title: Step 2 - Create a discount curve for each currency you want to valuate forward cashflows with
body: In addition, select an appropriate day count for your curve, and select appropriate interpolators / extrapolators.

title: Step 3 - Create a curve group for your currency discount curves
body: Third step is to create curve groups out of the yield curves you defined in step 2. Curve groups allow you to indicate which curve should be used for which currency, and that the yield curve you defined should be used as a discount curve. For example, you can link your LIBOR EUR DISCOUNT curve to your EUR currency as a DISCOUNT curve, when the system knows to use LIBOR EUR DISCOUNT curve to discount forward cashflows in EUR.

title: Step 3 - Create a curve group for your currency discount curves
body: You can set up your yield curve groups under the Yield curves preferences. First, Add a yield curve group for "Discount curves", and under the group, Add group item for each currency + discount curve pair. The code is automatically generated based on your selections:

title: Step 3 - Create a curve group for your currency discount curves
body: Security

title: Step 3 - Create a curve group for your currency discount curves
body: Select the currency you want to link a discount curve to.

title: Step 3 - Create a curve group for your currency discount curves
body: Curve type

title: Step 3 - Create a curve group for your currency discount curves
body: Select curve type DISCOUNT.

title: Step 3 - Create a curve group for your currency discount curves
body: Curve

title: Step 3 - Create a curve group for your currency discount curves
body: Select the curve you created in step 2.

title: Step 3 - Create a curve group for your currency discount curves
body: After this, the forward cashflows in the currency are discounted with the linked curve.

title: Administering documents
body: FA allows you to store documents in the system and link them from external sources. Documents are stored under contacts, portfolios, securities, transactions, and trade orders, but you can manage them on the system level in the Administration view, Documents tab. The documents are listed in a table that shows the document name, the document type as an icon, the date, time, and user who last modified the document, and the document tags.

title: Administering documents
body: The following section describe how you can search and mass-modify documents on the system level.

title: Search documents in the system
body: In the Administration view, Documents tab, you can search for and access documents. You can't view all documents stored in the system at once, but you can search for documents on different levels:

title: Search documents in the system
body: Search within a specific folder by selecting the folder by name in the drop-down menu.

title: Search documents in the system
body: Search from all documents in the system by selecting the root folder (empty or "/") in the drop-down menu.

title: Search documents in the system
body: You can make your search more specific with the following criteria:

title: Search documents in the system
body: Document name. Search for exact (case sensitive) or partial matches. For partial matches (beginning, middle, or end of a file name), use * or %. For example, "Contract*", "*Contract*" or "*Contract", respectively.

title: Search documents in the system
body: Document tags. Select tags to search with. This returns all documents with any of the selected tags.

title: Mass-modify documents
body: You can mass-modify documents with the buttons at the bottom of the Administration view, Documents tab. For example, you can categorize large numbers of documents quickly by tagging them simultaneously. You can:

title: Mass-modify documents
body: Delete all currently visible documents by clicking Delete document.

title: Mass-modify documents
body: Add or remove tags from all currently visible documents by clicking Tag documents. You can add new tags by entering them in the + Document tags field and remove tags by entering them in the - Document tags field.

title: Upload meeting note templates for FA Advisor
body: In FA Advisor, users can store meeting notes for customers. Meeting notes can be created as blank notes or from templates. Meeting note templates need to be written in the Markdown format with the text file extension (.txt).

title: Upload meeting note templates for FA Advisor
body: To add a meeting note template, do the following:

title: Upload meeting note templates for FA Advisor
body: Open Administration, Documents tab and select the folder "/fa-advisor-templates".

title: Upload meeting note templates for FA Advisor
body: Click Upload file or Upload link and upload or link the template as a file.

title: Upload meeting note templates for FA Advisor
body: Right-click the template, select Modify document, and add the tag "AdvisorNoteTemplate".

title: Upload meeting note templates for FA Advisor
body: Click Save.

title: Upload meeting note templates for FA Advisor
body: The meeting note template is now available as an option in FA Advisor.

title: Related links
body: Documents in FA User guide

title: Set up document signing notifications
body: FA allows you to send documents to be signed by your clients (see Document signing in FA User guide). When you send a document for signing, the FA system can send notifications and reminders to a client via email and SMS. You can customize the content of the notifications or use the default texts.

title: Enable notifications and reminders
body: You can define the notification settings by doing the following:

title: Enable notifications and reminders
body: Go to Tools → Administer → Signicat sign.

title: Enable notifications and reminders
body: Fill in the fields:

title: Enable notifications and reminders
body: Send email notifications and Send SMS notifications. Define when notifications are sent to the client. The following options are available:

title: Enable notifications and reminders
body: Always (all document signees need to have a valid email address or international phone number).

title: Enable notifications and reminders
body: If valid email address is found / If valid phone number is found.

title: Enable notifications and reminders
body: Never.

title: Enable notifications and reminders
body: Reminder frequency. Define when reminder notifications are sent to the client. You can select none (never send reminders), daily, every other day, or weekly.

title: Enable notifications and reminders
body: Click Done.

title: Enable notifications and reminders
body: Notifications are now set up and the system sends notification and reminder messages to your clients as defined.

title: Define notification content
body: You can customize the content of document signing notifications sent to your clients by creating your own message templates. By default, the FA system uses the default notification texts. To override the default texts, do the following:

title: Define notification content
body: Go to Preference → Reporting → Email and click New.

title: Define notification content
body: Fill in the fields:

title: Define notification content
body: Template name

title: Define notification content
body: For the initial notification, enter "SigningRequestEmail" for an email and "SigningRequestSMS" for an SMS. If you enabled notification reminders, you need to create separate templates for the reminder notifications and enter "SigningReminderEmail" or "SigningReminderSMS". If you don't set up templates for reminders, the initial notification text is used in reminders as well.

title: Define notification content
body: From (name), From (email address), Reply to

title: Define notification content
body: Name of sender, email address of sender, and reply email address. These fields are not used in the signing process (the system uses the email address "noreply@signicat.com").

title: Define notification content
body: Title

title: Define notification content
body: Title of notification message, used as the subject in email notifications.

title: Define notification content
body: Content

title: Define notification content
body: Notification text. You can:

title: Define notification content
body: Use dynamic keys. For example, you can use %%contact.name%% to address the recipient by name (see Preference - Reporting in FA Back reference).

title: Define notification content
body: Show the document name to the recipient by including ${documentNames}.

title: Define notification content
body: Show the URL for reviewing and signing the document by including ${taskUrl}.

title: Define notification content
body: Click Save.

title: Define notification content
body: The system now uses the custom template to send notifications or reminders to your clients.

title: User management view
body: The User management view allows you to manage FA Platform users and their access rights to applications. You can search for users by their User ID, first name, last name, and email using the fields at the top of the view. You can also filter the list and sort the results by clicking the column titles. For more information about the columns, see User details and account information.

title: User management view
body: In this view, you can also:

title: User management view
body: Save a view you created by clicking .

title: User management view
body: Restore the default or saved view by clicking . When viewing a saved view, you can also clear the view and return to the default by clicking .

title: User management view
body: Manage saved views by clicking .

title: User management view
body: Refresh the list by clicking in the top right.

title: User management view
body: View and edit user information by clicking a user in the list. The User details pane opens (see User details and account information).

title: User management view
body: Export the user list as an XLSX file.

title: User management view
body: For the whole list, click Export → Download as XLSX.

title: User management view
body: For parts of the list, select users and click Export → Download as XLSX.

title: User management view
body: The following sections describe how you can manage users, assign user roles, manage user authentication, and view and edit user and account information.

title: Manage users and roles
body: You can add new users in the system and deactivate or delete existing users.

title: Add a user
body: To create a user account:

title: Add a user
body: Click Add user at the top-right corner and fill in the user information:

title: Add a user
body: The User ID used as a username at login and Email (required fields).

title: Add a user
body: Linked contact to set up access to client data or access to FA Front access with the external identity provider.

title: Add a user
body: Other fields if needed. See User details and account information for details.

title: Add a user
body: Click Edit user roles in the User details pane and choose which apps your user can access and with what roles.

title: Add a user
body: To access an app, a user needs a role for it – a user without any roles can't access any application.

title: Add a user
body: Let the user know about their credentials and how to get a password.

title: Add a user
body: Send them the user ID – FA platform doesn't send this information automatically.

title: Add a user
body: Instruct the user to request a password reset link by clicking Forgot password on the login page.

title: Deactivate a user
body: If a user doesn't need to access the platform anymore, we recommend deactivating their account rather than deleting it – this maintains the user's history while preventing them from accessing FA.

title: Deactivate a user
body: To change the status for multiple users, choose the users in the list and click . To change the status for one user, click in the User details pane. You can see the user's status in the list of users:

title: Deactivate a user
body: Active – The user can log in to the FA platform.

title: Deactivate a user
body: Inactive – The user can't log in to the FA platform.

title: Delete a user
body: Deleting a user removes all user information from the system. A deleted user can’t log in. If you just want to disable a user and prevent them from logging in, consider deactivating the user instead of deleting the account. To delete a user, click in the User details pane.

title: Assign user roles
body: The Roles block in the User details pane shows the roles assigned to the user. Roles determine:

title: Assign user roles
body: The app the user can access. To access an app, the user needs at least one role within that app. For example, if a user has a right in FA Back, the user is allowed to access FA Back.

title: Assign user roles
body: The access rights within the app. For example, FA Back roles determine access rights through permission and FA Front roles determine access rights through the views defined for the role.

title: Assign user roles
body: To add or remove the user’s roles, click Edit user roles at the top of the User details pane.

title: Manage authentication
body: You can manage user authentication using the following options:

title: Password reset
body: You can force the user to reset their password on next login. To force a password reset for multiple users, choose the users in the list and click . To force password reset for a selected user, click in the User details pane, choose Force password reset on next login and save the changes.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Two-factor authentication is a login option that requires entering a verification code in addition to the basic credentials (user ID and password). You can check two-factor authentication status in the User details pane:

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Disabled – Two-factor authentication is turned off.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Enabled – Two-factor authentication is turned on. The user has logged in and completed the mobile authenticator setup.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Pending – Two-factor authentication is turned on. You chose “Enable two-factor authentication on next login”, but the user didn’t yet log in to complete the setup.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: To manage two-factor authentication, use the buttons (available depending on the two-factor authentication status):

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Enable two-factor authentication

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Enable two-factor authentication on the next login for the user.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Cancel two-factor authentication

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Cancel two-factor authentication request that is pending.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Disable two-factor authentication

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Disable two-factor authentication for the user.

title: Brute force detection
body: FA Platform uses brute force detection to identify attempts to guess a user’s password. Brute force detection temporarily disables the user's account after a certain number and frequency of login failures. The user account is disabled for one minute if:

title: Brute force detection
body: The user enters incorrect credentials twice within a second. This means that someone tries to guess the password programmatically.

title: Brute force detection
body: The user fails to enter correct credentials 5 times. After the account is disabled, every unsuccessful attempt increases the lock by one minute, up to one hour.

title: Brute force detection
body: To check if a user account is disabled by the brute force detection, open the User details pane and go to the Brute force detection section. It includes the following information:

title: Brute force detection
body: Status

title: Brute force detection
body: Brute force detection status of the user account: Blocked (deactivated by brute force detection), or Unblocked (active). A user blocked by brute force detection has to wait for up to 1 hour (depending on the number of unsuccessful login attempts) for the account to be unblocked.

title: Brute force detection
body: Total login attempts

title: Brute force detection
body: The number of failed login attempts.

title: Brute force detection
body: Last attempt

title: Brute force detection
body: The date and time of the last login attempt.

title: Brute force detection
body: IP address

title: Brute force detection
body: The IP address from which the last login attempt was made.

title: Brute force detection
body: To activate a blocked user account, choose Unblock and activate. Once unblocked, your user can log in again without waiting for the system to unblock the user after a certain time.

title: User details and account information
body: The list of users and the User details pane on the right show the following information:

title: User account information
body: User ID (required)

title: User account information
body: A unique user ID for logging in to FA and log the user's activities.

title: User account information
body: Email (required)

title: User account information
body: The user’s email to send a password reset link to the user, if the user clicks Forgot password on the login page.

title: User account information
body: First name, Last name

title: User account information
body: The user’s first and last name.

title: User account information
body: Linked contact

title: User account information
body: The corresponding contact in FA Back. Linked contact is needed to:

title: User account information
body: Grant access only to certain customers and portfolios (see the Set up limited visibility for one user and Set up limited visibility for many users sections in the FA Admin guide).

title: User account information
body: Allow online end users to view their own investments in FA Front. A user that has a linked contact has access to the investment information associated with this contact.

title: User account information
body: Linked contact external ID

title: User account information
body: The user’s external ID received from the external identity provider when the user logs in to FA Front. External ID is used to find a matching contact for the user. If you see this field, this means that FA failed to link a contact to the user. For example, there is no contact with such an ID or there are several contacts with this ID stored in FA. In this case, you can add a contact manually in the Linked contact field.

title: User account information
body: Status

title: User account information
body: The user account status: active (the user can log in to FA) or inactive (the user can't log in to the system). See Assign user roles for details.

title: Sessions
body: The Sessions block shows a list of currently active sessions for the user. For example, the same user might have logged in with different browsers, having multiple sessions open at the same time. The list shows:

title: Sessions
body: Application

title: Sessions
body: The apps where the user is logged in within the session. For example, the user might have FA Back and FA Front open in different tabs in the same browser, accessing both applications with a single login and a single session.

title: Sessions
body: Last access

title: Sessions
body: The date and time the user accessed an app within the session. If the user accesses only one app, this shows the time they logged in, or if your user accesses multiple apps, this shows the time the user last opened a new app.

title: Sessions
body: IP address

title: Sessions
body: Shows the IP address the user is logged in from.

title: Sessions
body: You can log the user out of all sessions by clicking Log out user from all sessions. The user will be able to use FA for a short time until their authentication expires, then they will get a "communication problem" and will be taken to the login page.

title: Last logins
body: The Last logins block shows date and time of the five last user logins.

title: Related links
body: Managing users in FA Admin guide

title: Related links
body: Authentication in FA Admin guide

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: # Code Required Name Description

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 1 c.contactId Yes Contact ID Unique ID for the contact (e.g. social security number or other unique identifier).

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 2 c.externalId No External contact ID E.g. social security number or other additional identification.

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 3 c.name Yes Name Contact name (e.g. first name and last name, company name, etc.).

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 4 c.type Yes Type Define as a number: 1 = Customer 2 = Asset manager 3 = Broker 4 = Accountant 5 = Issuer 6 = Custody 7 = Lead

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 5 c.juridical Yes Juridical form Juridical form code (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 6 c.status Yes Status Use the code of the status: A = Active P = Passive C = Closed

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 7 c.taxCountry Yes Tax country Country code (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 8 c.memo No Memo Text, memo information

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 9 c.classification Yes Classification Classification code (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 10 c.identity Yes Identity Identity code (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 11 c.address1 No Address 1

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 12 c.address2 No Address 2

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 13 c.zipCode No Zip code

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 14 c.city No City

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 15 c.country No Country

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 16 c.phone1 No Phone 1

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 17 c.phone2 No Phone 2

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 18 c.fax No Fax

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 19 c.email No Email

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 20 c.electronicCommunication No Electronic communication Define as a number: 1 = allow electronic communication 0 = not allowed

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 21 c.marketingCommunication No Marketing communication Define as a number: 1 = allow marketing communication 0 = not allowed

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 22 c.nationality No Nationality Country code (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 23 c.representatives No Representatives Comma-separated list of contact IDs representing the contact, for example, 1223,1224,1225. To import tag values for a contact representative, add them after ###: Add standalone tags as <representative's contact ID>###<tag name 1>#<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Standalone1#Standalone2Add single-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>-<tag name 1>#<group name>-<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Permission-View#Relationship type-AdvisorAdd multi-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>:<tag name 1>#<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Permission for trade orders:Make#Permission for trade orders:ModifyTo import multiple types of tags simultaneously, separate the tags with #. For example: 04012000###Permission-View#Employee:Finance#Employee:Accounting#Relationship type-Advisor#Standalone1#Standalone2 You can use *** syntax to add new representatives and keep existing ones (for example: ***,04012000###...). For details, see Updating contacts and portfolios. To add representatives to a contact without any existing representatives, add "???," at the beginning of the column's content (for example: ???,04012000####...). If the contact already has representatives, existing representatives will be kept and the new ones are not added.

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 24 c.language No Language Language code (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 25 c.subType No Sub type Contact sub type code (configured in the system). When a sub type is given, it will find its own parent contact type and override the given contact type's code (in column 4).

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 26 c.transactionExtIdLevel No Transaction no. level Define as a number: 1 = Portfolio level 2 = Contact level

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 27 c.contactExchanges No Settlement place Comma-separated list of contact settlement places with settlement place code (configured in the system) and counter information with BIC code. Use the following syntax to import settlement place information: <settlement place code>=<counter>. E.g. APKEFIHH=ESSEFIHX,MGTCBEBE=ESSEFIHX

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 28 c.tags No Tags Comma-separated list of tags. Tags import allows you to add new tags: Standalone tags are added with a <tag name>. For example: Fund,ContractOK.Single-select group tags should be added as <group name>-<tag name>. For example: office-Helsinki. If a contact already has a tag with the same group name, the tag is replaced.Multi-select group tags should be added as a comma-separated list of values <group name>:<tag name 1>,<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: Interests:Golf,Interests:Culture. If a contact already has tags with the same group name, the new tag is added to the existing ones. You can use three minuses (---) syntax to remove a tag: Standalone tags: ---<tag name>. For example: ---Fund,---ContractOK.Single-select group tags: ---<group name>-<tag name>. For example: —office-Helsinki.Multi-select group tags: ---<group name>:<tag name 1>,---<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: ---Interests:Golf,---Interests:Culture. For details, see Removing contact and portfolio values with three minuses (---).

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 29 c.classification2 No Classification 2 Classification 2 code (configured in the system).

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 30 c.classification3 No Classification 3 Classification 3 code (configured in the system).

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 31 c.profileAttributes No Profile Contact-specific profile (configured in the system). Use the following syntax to import / update profile information: <key>=<value>:<type>#<key>=<value>:<type> etc. Note that importing checkbox fields requires you to use the type "boolean" and importing date fields requires you to use the type "date" in the syntax. Profile import allows you to add or modify profile values with a specific key - existing profile values are not replaced or removed unless you specifically include their key within the import syntax. You can use three minuses (---) syntax to remove a profile attribute value. For example: ---<key>. For details, see Removing contact and portfolio values with three minuses (---).

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 32 c.extContactIdList No External IDs List of contact's external ID's. Use the following syntax <ext_id1=ext_name1>,<ext_id2=ext_name2> etc. If ext_id and ext_name combination for the same contact exist just use the existing one, otherwise create new one. If ext_id and ext_name combination exist but for a different contact, will show error message.

title: FA Format for importing contacts
body: 33 c.keyFigures No Key figures Define the key figure code and individual observations as date-value pairs as a comma-separated list with the format <code>=<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value&>&<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>:<code>=<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>,... E.g. AAA=2009-01-01=1.9,2010-01-01=1.10:TAX=2007-01-01=1,2010-01-01=2 When importing categorized key figures (e.g. 1=Low, 2=Medium, 3=High), prior to 3.7.7 you should use the "number" (e.g. 1, 2 or 3), and after 3.7.7 you should use the "text" (e.g. Low, Medium, High). You can use *** syntax to add new observations and keep the existing ones. For example: ***:BBB=2007-01-01=1,2010-01-01=3. For details, see Updating contacts and portfolios.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 19 p.accounts No Accounts  A colon-separated (:) list of the portfolio accounts. To add accounts to a portfolio, use the following syntax: <Account no.>,<Currency with currency code>,<Name>,<Visibility as 0=not visible 1=visible>,<Shared as 0=not shared 1=shared>,<Priority as integer>;<BIC code>,<Mandate>,<Secondary account number>,<Category>,<Account type as 0=not cash, 1=cash, 2=credit>,<Hide if zero as 0=don’t hide, 1=hide>,<Tags separated with #>,<Issuer with contact ID>,<Calendar with the calendar code>,<Fixing as a number>,<Base instrument with the security code>,<Spread as a number>,<Exclude balance as 0=don't exclude, 1=exclude>,<Shared with all as 0=not shared, 1=shared>, <Shared to all parent portfolio's subportfolios as 0=not shared, 1=shared>, <Decimals for transactions as a number>, <Transaction type code>, <Offset days as an integer>. For example, a list of two accounts: FI12 3456 78,EUR,Euro account,1,0,1,NDEAFIHHXXX,12345678,12345-678,Bank account,1,0,Client account#Status OK:234-321,USD,Dollar account,0,1,2,,,,,1,0,Client account#Status OK,,Act/360,0.2,LIBOR,1.5,0,0,0,4 The account currency (second in the syntax) is validated to be a valid currency in the system. Supported calendar codes: 1/130/360ISDA30/360 PSA30E+/36030E/36030E/360 ISDA30U/36030U/36030U/360 EOMAct/360Act/364Act/365 ActualAct/365.25Act/365FAct/365LAct/366Act/366.375Act/Act AFBAct/Act ICMAAct/Act ISDAAct/Act YearNL/365 You can use *** syntax to add new accounts for the portfolio while keeping the old ones, but this is not required. Without ***, old values are still preserved. For example: ***:<Account>:<Account>). For details, see Updating contacts and portfolios. To update the account number of an existing account, use the syntax "[old account no]new account no" in the first field of the account syntax. For example, if you want to update an account number from 1000 to 1010, define the account number in the syntax as [1000]1010. To keep the accounts unchanged, import an empty value in the field. Existing accounts cannot be removed using import.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 20 p.assetManagers No Asset managers Portfolio's asset managers. Contact IDs as a comma-separated list. To import representative tag values, add them after ###. Standalone tags are added as <contact ID>###<tag name>. For example: 04012000##parent.Single-select group tags are added as <contact ID>###<group name>-<tag name>. For example: 04012000##relative-parent.Multi-select group tags are added as a comma-separated list of values: <contact ID>###<group name>:<tag name 1>,<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Employee:Finance,Employee:Accounting.

E.g. transaction=2.3, management=1.5 You can use *** syntax to add fees to the portfolio and keep the existing ones. For example: ***,payment=3,withdrawal=3.9. For details, see Updating contacts and portfolios.

If ext_id and ext_name combination exist but for a different portfolio, will show error message.
